answerDescription: When Paul was ready to embark on his second missionary journey, he asked Barnabas to join him, but a disagreement caused them to split up. Barnabas went to Cyprus with John Mark, and Paul took Silas to Asia Minor.

question: When an angel released Peter from prison and he went to the house of John Mark, what servant answered the door?
answerDescription: ACTS 12:12-14: He went to the house of Mary the mother of John, also called Mark, where many people had gathered and were praying. Peter knocked at the outer entrance, and a servant named Rhoda came to answer the door. When she recognized Peter's voice, she was so overjoyed she ran back without opening it and exclaimed, "Peter is at the door!"

question: What was the name of the young man who fell out of a window while Paul was preaching?
answerDescription: ACTS 20:7-11: Paul spoke to the people and, because he intended to leave the next day, kept on talking until midnight. There were many lamps in the upstairs room where we were meeting. Seated in a window was a young man named Eutychus, who was sinking into a deep sleep as Paul talked on and on. When he was sound asleep, he fell to the ground from the third story and was picked up dead. Paul went down, threw himself on the young man and put his arms around him. "Don't be alarmed," he said. "He's alive!" Then he went upstairs again and broke bread and ate.

question: What was the name of Judas Iscariot's father?
answerDescription: JOHN 13:26: Then, dipping the piece of bread, he gave it to Judas, the son of Simon Iscariot.

question: Who was Saul's first missionary companion?
answerDescription: ACTS 13:2-3: While they were worshiping the Lord and fasting, the Holy Spirit said, "Set apart for me Barnabas and Saul for the work to which I have called them." So after they had fasted and prayed, they placed their hands on them and sent them off.

question: Who tried to buy the gift of bestowing the Holy Spirit from Peter and John?
answerDescription: ACTS 8:18-20: When Simon saw that the Spirit was given at the laying on of the apostles' hands, he offered them money and said, "Give me also this ability so that everyone on whom I lay my hands may receive the Holy Spirit." Peter answered: "May your money perish with you, because you thought you could buy the gift of God with money!"

question: Who was the first known European convert to Christianity?
answerDescription: Lydia of Thyatira is generally regarded as the first documented convert to Christianity in Europe. Several Christian denominations have designated her a saint.

question: What was the name of John the Baptist's mother?
answerDescription: According to the Gospel of Luke, Elizabeth, also spelled Elisabeth or Elisheba, was the mother of John the Baptist and the wife of Zechariah.

question: After the Prodigal Son ran out of money, what job did he find?
answerDescription: LUKE 15:15: So he went and hired himself out to a citizen of that country, who sent him to his fields to feed pigs.

question: Who did God strike dead for withholding money from the church?
answerDescription: According to the fifth chapter of Acts, Ananias and his wife Sapphira were members of the early Christian church in Jerusalem. The account records their sudden deaths after selling a piece of property and withholding a portion of the proceeds for themselves.

question: In the fourth chapter of Revelation, John of Patmos sees four living creatures: a lion, an ox, an eagle, and a _____.
answerDescription: REVELATION 4:7: The first living creature was like a lion, the second was like an ox, the third had a face like a man, the fourth was like a flying eagle.

question: How did James, the brother of John, die?
answerDescription: ACTS 12:1-2: It was about this time that King Herod arrested some who belonged to the church, intending to persecute them. He had James, the brother of John, put to death with the sword.

question: How many books are there in the Old Testament?
answerDescription: There are 39 books in the Old Testament: Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers, Deuteronomy, Joshua, Judges, Ruth, 1 Samuel, 2 Samuel, 1 Kings, 2 Kings, 1 Chronicles, 2 Chronicles, Ezra, Nehemiah, Esther, Job, Psalms, Proverbs, Ecclesiastes, Song of Songs, Isaiah, Jeremiah, Lamentations, Ezekiel, Daniel, Hosea, Joel, Amos, Obadiah, Jonah, Micah, Nahum, Habakkuk, Zephaniah, Haggai, Zechariah, and Malachi.

question: What was the first of the Ten Commandments?
options: YOU SHALL HAVE NO OTHER GODS BEFORE ME
answerDescription: EXODUS 20:3: You shall have no other gods before me.

question: What kind of bird brought Elijah food while he hid in the Kerith Ravine, east of Jordan?
answerDescription: 1 KINGS 17:1-6: Now Elijah the Tishbite, from Tishbe in Gilead, said to Ahab, "As the LORD, the God of Israel, lives, whom I serve, there will be neither dew nor rain in the next few years except at my word." Then the word of the LORD came to Elijah: "Leave here, turn eastward and hide in the Kerith Ravine, east of Jordan. You will drink from the brook, and I have ordered the ravens to feed you there." So he did what the LORD had told him. He went to the Kerith Ravine, east of the Jordan, and stayed there. The ravens brought him bread and meat in the morning and bread and meat in the evening, and he drank from the brook.

question: What language was most of the Old Testament originally written in?
answerDescription: The Old Testament was mainly written in Biblical Hebrew, with some portions (notably in Daniel and Ezra) in Biblical Aramaic. Biblical Hebrew, sometimes called Classical Hebrew, is an archaic form of the Hebrew language. The very first translation of the Hebrew Bible was into Greek.

question: What did Jacob vow at Bethel?
options: TO TITHE A TENTH OF HIS INCOME
answerDescription: GENESIS 28:20-22: Then Jacob made a vow, saying, "If God will be with me, and keep me in this way that I am going, and give me bread to eat and clothing to put on, so that I come back to my father's house in peace, then the Lord shall be my God. And this stone which I have set as a pillar shall be God's house, and of all that You give me I will surely give a tenth to You."

question: Which of Jacob's wives died giving birth his son Benjamin?
answerDescription: GENESIS 25:16-18: Then they moved on from Bethel. While they were still some distance from Ephrath, Rachel began to give birth and had great difficulty. And as she was having great difficulty in childbirth, the midwife said to her, "Don't despair, for you have another son." As she breathed her last--for she was dying--she named her son Ben-Oni. But his father named him Benjamin.

question: Why did God put a mark on Cain?
answerDescription: GENESIS 4:15: But the Lord said to him, "Not so; anyone who kills Cain will suffer vengeance seven times over." Then the Lord put a mark on Cain so that no one who found him would kill him.

question: What kind of stew did Esau sell his birthright for?
answerDescription:
GENESIS 25:29-24: 29 Once when Jacob was cooking some stew, Esau came in from the open country, famished. 30 He said to Jacob, "Quick, let me have some of that red stew! I'm famished!" (That is why he was also called Edom.)
31 Jacob replied, "First sell me your birthright." 32 "Look, I am about to die," Esau said. "What good is the birthright to me?" 33 But Jacob said, "Swear to me first." So he swore an oath to him, selling his birthright to Jacob. 34 Then Jacob gave Esau some bread and some lentil stew. He ate and drank, and then got up and left.

question: What was the first plague that the Egyptian magicians could not duplicate?
answerDescription: EXODUS 8:17-18: When Aaron stretched out his hand with the staff and struck the dust of the ground, gnats came on people and animals. All the dust throughout the land of Egypt became gnats. 18 But when the magicians tried to produce gnats by their secret arts, they could not.

question: According to Joshua, one Israelite could rout how many inhabitants of Canaan?
answerDescription: JOSHUA 23:10: One of you routs a thousand, because the Lord your God fights for you, just as he promised.

question: Who was the only queen to occupy the throne of Judah?
answerDescription: Athaliah was queen consort of Judah as the wife of King Jehoram, a descendant of King David, and later queen regnant for six years. As queen, Athaliah used her power to establish the worship of Baal in Judah.

question: What king of Judah stripped the gold from the temple doors?
answerDescription: 2 KINGS 18:16: At this time Hezekiah king of Judah stripped off the gold with which he had covered the doors and doorposts of the temple of the Lord, and gave it to the king of Assyria.

question: What kind of meat did God provide for the Israelites in the desert?
answerDescription: NUMBERS 11:31: The Lord sent a wind from the sea that brought quails and dropped them all around the camp. There were quails on the ground about three feet deep as far as you could walk in a day in any direction.

question: How did the Israelites destroy the wall of Jericho?
answerDescription: JOSHUA 6:20: When the trumpets sounded, the army shouted, and at the sound of the trumpet, when the men gave a loud shout, the wall collapsed; so everyone charged straight in, and they took the city.

question: Who did God choose as his "signet ring"?
answerDescription: HAGGAI 2:23: "On that day," declares the Lord Almighty, "I will take you, my servant Zerubbabel son of Shealtiel," declares the Lord, "and I will make you like my signet ring, for I have chosen you," declares the Lord Almighty.

question: What Old Testament prophet told of the Valley of Dry Bones?
answerDescription: In chapter 37 of the Book of Ezekiel, the prophet sees himself standing in a valley full of dry human bones. Before him the bones connect into human figures, then the bones become covered with tendon tissues, flesh and skin. Then God reveals the bones to the prophet as the People of Israel in exile and commands the Prophet to carry another prophecy in order to revitalize these human figures, to resurrect them and to bring them to the Land of Israel.

question: What did God change Jacob's name to?
answerDescription: GENESIS 35:9-10: 9 After Jacob returned from Paddan Aram, God appeared to him again and blessed him. 10 God said to him, "Your name is Jacob, but you will no longer be called Jacob; your name will be Israel."

question: What special instructions were the Israelites given for eating sacrificial lambs during Passover?
answerDescription: EXODUS 12:46: It must be eaten inside the house; take none of the meat outside the house. Do not break any of the bones.

question: Why was Moses angry with the Israelite army after they defeated the Midianites?
options: BECAUSE THEY KEPT PLUNDER FOR THEMSELVES
BECAUSE THEY LOOTED THE MIDIANITE TOWNS
answerDescription: NUMBERS 31:15-18: 15 "Have you allowed all the women to live?" he asked them. 16 "They were the ones who followed Balaam's advice and enticed the Israelites to be unfaithful to the Lord in the Peor incident, so that a plague struck the Lord's people. 17 Now kill all the boys. And kill every woman who has slept with a man, 18 but save for yourselves every girl who has never slept with a man."

question: Whose descendants became two tribes of Israel?
answerDescription: JOSHUA 14:4: For Joseph's descendants had become two tribes--Manasseh and Ephraim.

question: Who struck down 600 Philistines with an oxgoad?
answerDescription: JUDGES 3:31: After Ehud came Shamgar son of Anath, who struck down six hundred Philistines with an oxgoad. He too saved Israel.

question: In whose field did Ruth glean leftover grain?
answerDescription: RUTH 2:3: As it turned out, she was working in a field belonging to Boaz, who was from the clan of Elimelek.

question: What is the last word in the Old Testament?
answerDescription: MALACHI 4:5-6: See, I will send you the prophet Elijah before the great and dreadful say of the LORD comes. He will turn the hearts of the fathers to their children, and the hearts of the children to their fathers; or else I will come and strike the land with a curse.

question: Why did Esau take one of Ishmael's daughters as his wife?
options: SHE WAS PREGNANT WITH HIS CHILD
THE DAUGHTERS OF CANAAN DISPLEASED HIS FATHER
answerDescription: Esau saw that the daughters of Canaan did not please his father Isaac. So Esau went to Ishmael and took Mahalath the daughter of Ishmael, Abraham's son, the sister of Nebajoth, to be his wife in addition to the wives he had.

question: What did God provide for Abraham to offer as a burnt offering instead of his son Isaac?
answerDescription: GENESIS 22:13: Abraham looked up and there in a thicket he saw a ram caught by its horns. He went over and took the ram and sacrificed it as a burnt offering instead of his son.

question: What did Miriam take in her hand when God drowned Pharaoh's army in the Red Sea?
answerDescription: EXODUS 15:19-20: 19When Pharaoh's horses, chariots and horsemen went into the sea, the Lord brought the waters of the sea back over them, but the Israelites walked through the sea on dry ground. 20 Then Miriam the prophet, Aaron's sister, took a timbrel in her hand, and all the women followed her, with timbrels and dancing.

question: If an Israelite found a dead animal, they weren't allowed to eat it, but they were allowed to ________.
options: GIVE IT TO A FOREIGNER TO EAT
answerDescription: DEUTERONOMY 14:21: Do not eat anything you find already dead. You may give it to the foreigner residing in any of your towns, and they may eat it, or you may sell it to any other foreigner.

question: In ancient Israel what was the method of legalizing transactions?
answerDescription: RUTH 4:7: Now in earlier times in Israel, for the redemption and transfer of property to become final, one party took off his sandal and gave it to the other. This was the method of legalizing transactions in Israel.

question: Which of the following animals were Israelites allowed to eat in the Old Testament?
answerDescription: DEUTERONOMY 14:3-8: Do not eat any detestable thing. These are the animals you may eat: the ox, the sheep, the goat, the deer, the gazelle, the roe deer, the wild goat, the ibex, the antelope and the mountain sheep. You may eat any animal that has a split hoof divided in two and that chews the cud. However, of those that chew the cud or that have a split hoof completely divided you may not eat the camel, the rabbit or the coney. Although they chew the cud, they do not have a split hoof; they are ceremoniously unclean for you. The pig is also unclean; although it has a split hoof, it does not chew the cud. You are not to eat their meat or touch their carcasses.

question: Which of the following is NOT a book of the Old Testament?
answerDescription: The Book of Enoch is NOT included in the standard Old Testament. It is an apocryphal work attributed to Enoch, the great-grandfather of Noah. Habakkuk, Amos, and Zephaniah are all books of the Old Testament.

question: What did the Ark of the Covenant contain?
answerDescription: HEBREWS 9:4: This ark contained the gold jar of manna, Aaron's staff that had budded, and the stone tablets of the covenant.

question: What was the first bird Noah sent out from the ark?
answerDescription: GENESIS 8:6-9: So it came to pass, at the end of forty days, that Noah opened the window of the ark which he had made. Then he sent out a raven, which kept going to and fro until the waters had dried up from the earth. He also sent out from himself a dove, to see if the waters had receded from the face of the ground. But the dove found no resting place for the sole of her foot, and she returned into the ark to him, for the waters were on the face of the whole earth.

question: How tall was Goliath?
answerDescription: 1 SAMUEL 17:4: And a champion went out from the camp of the Philistines, named Goliath, from Gath, whose height was six cubits and a span. (Taking a cubit to be approximately eighteen inches and a span to equal six, this figures to a height of approximately nine feet, six inches.)

question: What did God ask Abraham to sacrifice to him on Mount Moriah?
answerDescription: GENESIS 22:9-10: Then they came to the place of which God had told him. And Abraham built an altar there and placed the wood in order; and he bound Isaac his son and laid him on the altar, upon the wood. And Abraham stretched out his hand and took the knife to slay his son.

question: How did Rahab let the invading Israelites know to spare her house?
options: TIED A RED CORD IN HER WINDOW
answerDescription: JOSHUA 2:17-19: So the men said to her: "We will be blameless of this oath of yours which you have made us swear, unless, when we come into the land, you bind this line of scarlet cord in the window through which you let us down, and unless you bring your father, your mother, your brothers, and all your father's household to your own home. So it shall be that whoever goes outside the doors of your house into the street, his blood shall be on his own head, and we will be guiltless. And whoever is with you in the house, his blood shall be on our head if a hand is laid on him.

question: Who was known as "the weeping prophet"?
answerDescription: Jeremiah was the son of Hilkiah, a Jewish priest from the Benjamite village of Anathoth. The difficulties he encountered, as described in the books of Jeremiah and Lamentations, have prompted scholars to refer to him as "the weeping prophet".

question: Who succeeded Moses as leader of the Israelites?
answerDescription: DEUTERONOMY 34:9: Now Joshua the son of Nun was full of the spirit of wisdom, for Moses had laid his hands on him; so the children of Israel heeded him, and did as the Lord had commanded Moses.

question: How many decks did Noah's ark have?
answerDescription: GENESIS 6:16: Put a door in the side of the ark and make lower, middle and upper decks.

question: Who was buried in the cave of Machpelah?
answerDescription: GENESIS 23:19: Afterward Abraham buried his wife Sarah in the cave in the field of Machpelah near Mamre (which is at Hebron) in the land of Canaan.

question: How many times did Laban change Jacob's wages?
answerDescription: GENESIS 31:4-7: 4 So Jacob sent word to Rachel and Leah to come out to the fields where his flocks were. 5 He said to them, "I see that your father's attitude toward me is not what it was before, but the God of my father has been with me. 6 You know that I've worked for your father with all my strength, 7 yet your father has cheated me by changing my wages ten times.

question: Which of Joseph's brothers rescued him when the others wanted to kill him?
answerDescription: GENESIS 37:17-22: So Joseph went after his brothers and found them near Dothan. 18 But they saw him in the distance, and before he reached them, they plotted to kill him. 19 "Here comes that dreamer!" they said to each other. 20 "Come now, let's kill him and throw him into one of these cisterns and say that a ferocious animal devoured him. Then we'll see what comes of his dreams." 21 When Reuben heard this, he tried to rescue him from their hands. "Let's not take his life," he said. 22 "Don't shed any blood. Throw him into this cistern here in the wilderness, but don't lay a hand on him." Reuben said this to rescue him from them and take him back to his father.

question: Which wind brought the plague of locusts to Egypt?
answerDescription: EXODUS 10:13 So Moses stretched out his staff over Egypt, and the Lord made an east wind blow across the land all that day and all that night. By morning the wind had brought the locusts.

question: Who wore the Urim and the Thummim over his heart?
answerDescription: EXODUS 28:30: Also put the Urim and the Thummim in the breastpiece, so they may be over Aaron's heart whenever he enters the presence of the Lord. Thus Aaron will always bear the means of making decisions for the Israelites over his heart before the Lord

question: On what day of Creation did God create man?
answerDescription: GENESIS 1:27-31: So God created man in his own image, in the image of God he created him; male and female he created them. God blessed them and said to them, "Be fruitful and increase in number; fill the earth and subdue it. Rule over the fish of the sea and the birds of the air and over every living creature that moves on the ground." Then God said, "I give you every seed-bearing plant on the face of the whole earth and every tree that has fruit with seed in it. They will be yours for food. And to all the beasts of the earth and all the birds of the air and all the creatures that move on the ground--everything that has the breath of life in it--I give every green plant for food." And it was so. God saw all that he had made, and it was very good. And there was evening, and there was morning--the sixth day.

question: What was the name of Adam's third son?
answerDescription: GENESIS 4:25: Adam lay with his wife again, and she gave birth to a son and named him Seth, saying, "God has granted me another child in place of Abel, since Cain killed him." Seth also had a son and named him Enosh. At that time men began to call on the name of the Lord.

question: At the time of the census conducted by Moses in the first chapter of Numbers, which of the twelve tribes of Israel was the smallest?
answerDescription: At the time of the census conducted by Moses in the first chapter of Numbers, Manasseh was the smallest tribe with only 32,200 members.

question: Who was the mother of Samuel?
answerDescription: SAMUEL 1: 19-20: Elkanah made love to his wife Hannah, and the Lord remembered her. So in the course of time Hannah became pregnant and gave birth to a son. She named him Samuel, saying, "Because I asked the Lord for him."

question: Which tribe made David king after Saul's death?
answerDescription: 2 SAMUEL 2:7: Now then, be strong and brave, for Saul your master is dead, and the people of Judah have anointed me king over them.

question: What was the name of the bronze snake Moses made to protect the Israelites from venomous snake bites?
answerDescription: 2 KINGS 18:4: [Hezekiah] broke into pieces the bronze snake Moses had made, for up to that time the Israelites had been burning incense to it. (It was called Nehushtan.)

question: How many sons did Jacob have?
answerDescription: Jacob had twelve sons and at least one daughter, by his two wives, Leah and Rachel, and by their handmaidens Bilhah and Zilpah. Jacob's twelve sons, named in Genesis, were Reuben, Simeon, Levi, Judah, Dan, Naphtali, Gad, Asher, Issachar, Zebulun, Joseph, and Benjamin. His only daughter mentioned in Genesis is Dinah.

question: What was the name of Job's eldest daughter?
answerDescription: JOB 42:13-15: He also had seven sons and three daughters. And he called the name of the first Jemimah, the name of the second Keziah, and the name of the third Keren-Happuch. In all the land were found no women so beautiful as the daughters of Job; and their father gave them an inheritance among their brothers.

question: Who was the longest reigning king of Judah?
answerDescription: After a reign of 55 years, the longest in the history of Judah, Manasseh died around 643 BC and was buried in the garden of Uzza.

question: What was the name of Aaron's wife?
answerDescription: NUMBERS 21:23: Aaron married Elisheba, daughter of Amminadab and sister of Nahshon, and she bore him Nadab and Abihu, Eleazar and Ithamar.

question: Who was the nurse of Isaac's wife Rebecca?
answerDescription: GENESIS 35:8: Now Deborah, Rebekah's nurse, died and was buried under the oak outside Bethel. So it was named Allon Bakuth.

question: Which of Jacob's sons slept with his concubine Bilhah?
answerDescription: GENESIS 35:22: While Israel was living in that region, Reuben went in and slept with his father's concubine Bilhah, and Israel heard of it.

question: Which of Saul's sons became king after his death?
answerDescription: 2 SAMUEL 2:10: Ish-Bosheth son of Saul was forty years old when he became king over Israel, and he reigned two years. The tribe of Judah, however, remained loyal to David.

question: Which tribe of Israel was charged with watching over the tent of testimony?
answerDescription: NUMBERS 18:2: And with you bring your brother also, the tribe of Levi, the tribe of your father, that they may join you and minister to you while you and your sons with you are before the tent of the testimony.

question: Which of the twelve tribes provided Israel with its first king?
answerDescription: The tribe of Benjamin provided Israel with its first king, Saul, and was later assimilated into the tribe of Judah.

question: What name is commonly given to the first five books of the Old Testament?
answerDescription: The Torah, or Pentateuch, is the first five books of the Old Testament. According to tradition, these books were written by Moses.

question: Who was the wife of Uriah the Hittite?
answerDescription: 2 SAMUEL 11:3-4: So David sent and inquired about the woman. And someone said, "Is this not Bathsheba, the daughter of Eliam, the wife of Uriah the Hittite?" Then David sent messengers, and took her; and she came to him, and he lay with her, for she was cleansed from her impurity; and she returned to her house.

question: From which of Adam's body parts did God create Eve?
answerDescription: GENESIS 2:21-22: And the Lord God caused a deep sleep to fall on Adam, and he slept; and He took one of his ribs, and closed up the flesh in its place. Then the rib which the Lord God had taken from man He made into a woman.

question: What did David use to kill Goliath?
answerDescription: 1 SAMUEL 17:49-50: Then David put his hand in his bag and took out a stone; and he slung it and struck the Philistine in his forehead, so that the stone sank into his forehead, and he fell on his face to the earth. So David prevailed over the Philistine with a sling and a stone, and struck the Philistine and killed him.

question: What was the first plague God sent on Egypt?
answerDescription: EXODUS 7:14-17: So the Lord said to Moses: "Pharaoh's heart is hard; he refuses to let the people go. Go to Pharaoh in the morning, when he goes out to the water, and you shall stand by the river's bank to meet him; and the rod which was turned to a serpent you shall take in your hand. And you shall say to him, 'The Lord God of the Hebrews has sent me to you, saying, "Let My people go, that they may serve Me in the wilderness"; but indeed, until now you would not hear! Thus says the Lord: "By this you shall know that I am the Lord. Behold, I will strike the waters which are in the river with the rod that is in my hand, and they shall be turned to blood.

question: Where did Moses die?
answerDescription: DEUTERONOMY 34:5-6: So Moses the servant of the Lord died there in the land of Moab, according to the word of the Lord. And He buried him in a valley in the land of Moab, opposite Beth Peor; but no one knows his grave to this day.

question: When God appeared in the burning bush, what disease did he inflict on Moses?
options: HE DIDN'T GIVE HIM ANY DISEASE
answerDescription: EXODUS 4:6-7: 6 Then the Lord said, "Put your hand inside your cloak." So Moses put his hand into his cloak, and when he took it out, the skin was leprous--it had become as white as snow. 7 "Now put it back into your cloak," he said. So Moses put his hand back into his cloak, and when he took it out, it was restored, like the rest of his flesh.

question: What was the punishment for working on the Sabbath?
answerDescription: EXODUS 31:15: For six days work is to be done, but the seventh day is a day of sabbath rest, holy to the Lord. Whoever does any work on the Sabbath day is to be put to death.

question: What were Israelites with a defiling disease required to do?
options: COVER THE LOWER PART OF THEIR FACE
answerDescription: LEVITICUS 13:45: Anyone with such a defiling disease must wear torn clothes, let their hair be unkempt, cover the lower part of their face and cry out, "Unclean! Unclean!"

question: Which Israelite tribe was not counted in the first census?
answerDescription: NUMBERS 1:48-50: 48 The Lord had said to Moses: 49 "You must not count the tribe of Levi or include them in the census of the other Israelites. 50 Instead, appoint the Levites to be in charge of the tabernacle of the covenant law.

question: At what age were the Levites required to retire from active service at the tent of meeting?
answerDescription: NUMBERS 8:23-25: 23 The Lord said to Moses, 24 "This applies to the Levites: Men twenty-five years old or more shall come to take part in the work at the tent of meeting, 25 but at the age of fifty, they must retire from their regular service and work no longer.

question: How did God punish Korah son of Izhar for grumbling against Moses?
answerDescription: NUMBERS 16: 31-33: The ground under them split apart 32 and the earth opened its mouth and swallowed them and their households, and all those associated with Korah, together with their possessions. 33 They went down alive into the realm of the dead, with everything they owned; the earth closed over them, and they perished and were gone from the community.

question: Why did God give the land of Canaan to the Israelites?
options: BECAUSE THERE WAS NO OTHER PLACE FOR THEM
BECAUSE IT HAD ORIGINALLY BELONGED TO THEM
answerDescription: DEUTERONOMY 9:4: After the Lord your God has driven them out before you, do not say to yourself, "The Lord has brought me here to take possession of this land because of my righteousness." No, it is on account of the wickedness of these nations that the Lord is going to drive them out before you.

question: How many sons did Gideon have?
answerDescription: JUDGES 8:30: 30 He had seventy sons of his own, for he had many wives. 31 His concubine, who lived in Shechem, also bore him a son, whom he named Abimelek.

question: How did Samson's wife die?
answerDescription: JUDGES 15:6: When the Philistines asked, "Who did this?" they were told, "Samson, the Timnite's son-in-law, because his wife was given to his companion." So the Philistines went up and burned her and her father to death.

question: In what city did American colonists famously dress as Native Americans and dump an entire shipment of East India Company tea into the harbor?
answerDescription: The Boston Tea Party was a political protest by the Sons of Liberty on December 16, 1773. The demonstrators, some disguised as Native Americans, in defiance of the Tea Act of May 10, 1773, destroyed an entire shipment of tea sent by the East India Company. The British government responded harshly and the episode escalated into the American Revolution.

question: Who was one of the most famous and successful "conductors" on the Underground Railroad?
answerDescription: The Underground Railroad was a network of secret routes and safe houses established in the United States during the early to mid-19th century, and used by enslaved African-Americans to escape into free states. American abolitionist Harriet Tubman, who had been born into slavery herself, made 13 trips to the South, helping to free over 70 people.

question: How many people were accused of witchcraft during the Salem witch trials?
answerDescription: More than two hundred people were accused. Thirty were found guilty, nineteen of whom were executed by hanging (fourteen women and five men). One other man, Giles Corey, was pressed to death for refusing to plead, and at least five people died in jail.

question: Walt Whitman's poem "Oh Captain, My Captain" was written about which U.S. President?
answerDescription: "O Captain! My Captain!" was written in 1865 in response to the death of Abraham Lincoln. It was the only one of Whitman's poem to appear in anthologies during his lifetime.

question: What fraction of a person did slaves originally count as in the U.S. Constitution?
answerDescription: The Three-Fifths Compromise was a compromise reached between delegates from southern states and those from northern states during the 1787 United States Constitutional Convention. The debate was over whether, and if so, how, slaves would be counted when determining a state's total population for legislative representation and taxing purposes.

question: What was the name of civilian colonists who independently organized to form militia companies during the American Revolutionary War?
answerDescription: The minutemen were among the first to fight in the American Revolution. Their teams constituted about a quarter of the entire militia and were known for being ready at a minute's notice.

question: Who was the first American in space?
answerDescription: On May 5, 1961, Alan Shepard piloted the Mercury-Redstone 3 mission and became the first American to travel into space. He named his spacecraft Freedom 7. There was just enough room for one person. When reporters asked Shepard what he'd thought about as he sat atop the Redstone rocket, waiting for liftoff, he replied, "The fact that every part of this ship was built by the lowest bidder."

question: Which U.S. vice president killed Alexander Hamilton?
answerDescription: Aaron Burr, Thomas Jefferson's VP, shot and killed his political rival Alexander Hamilton in an 1804 duel. Although he was never tried for the illegal duel, Hamilton's death ended Burr's political career as Jefferson dumped him from the ticket in the next election.

question: What herbicide/defoliant was used by the U.S. military during the Vietnam War?
answerDescription: The U.S. Military used many herbicides/defoliants during the Vietnam War, including Agent Blue, Agent Green, Agent White, Agent Purple, Agent Pink, and Agent Orange. Agent Orange, however, has become the most infamous of this group because it was later shown to have toxic dioxin contaminants which have been blamed for various health problems and birth defects among both the general Vietnamese population and U.S. soldiers who were exposed to it.

question: Who helped launch the civil rights movement in 1955 by refusing to give her seat to a white passenger on an Alabama bus?
answerDescription: On December 1, 1955, in Montgomery, Alabama, Rosa Parks rejected bus driver James F. Blake's order to relinquish her seat in the "colored section" to a white passenger, after the whites-only section was filled. Parks' act of defiance and the subsequent Montgomery bus boycott became important symbols of the movement, and she became an international icon of resistance to racial segregation.

question: Who is best known for his midnight ride alerting the colonial militia to the approach of British forces?
answerDescription: Paul Revere's Midnight Ride occurred on the night of April 18, 1775, immediately before the battles of Lexington and Concord, the first engagements of the American Revolutionary War. By giving advance warning of the British Army's actions, the ride played a crucial role in the colonists' victory in the subsequent battles.

question: What was the last battle of the American Civil War?
answerDescription: The Battle of Palmito Ranch was fought May 12 and 13, 1865, on the banks of the Rio Grande east of Brownsville, Texas. It took place more than a month after the general surrender of Confederate forces at Appomattox Court House, in the distant Eastern Theater. Union Private John J. Williams of the 34th Indiana Infantry Regiment is believed to have been the last man killed during the engagement, likely making him the final combat death of the entire war.

question: Who was the only U.S. President to serve more than two terms?
answerDescription: Franklin D. Roosevelt is the only President of the United States to serve more than two terms in office. In response to this unprecedented achievement, the 22nd Amendment limiting Presidential terms was passed by Congress in 1947 and ratified by the states in 1951.

question: Which first lady was accused of poisoning her husband?
answerDescription: As Florence Harding did not request an autopsy and also destroyed many of her husband's papers, a conspiracy theory was put forward in The Strange Death of President Harding, sensationally claiming that she had poisoned her husband, a suggestion that has been entirely discredited, along with the book in which it was published.

question: Which founding father is known for his large signature on the United States Declaration of Independence?
answerDescription: John Hancock is remembered for his large and stylish signature on the United States Declaration of Independence, so much so that the term "John Hancock" has become a synonym in the United States for one's signature.

question: What was the nickname of the cavalry regiment Theodore Roosevelt commanded during the Spanish-American War?
answerDescription: Under Roosevelt's leadership, the Rough Riders became famous for their charge up Kettle Hill on July 1, 1898. Diversity characterized the regiment, which included Ivy Leaguers, professional and amateur athletes, upscale gentlemen, cowboys, frontiersmen, Native Americans, hunters, miners, prospectors, former soldiers, tradesmen, and sheriffs.

question: Who did Pocahontas marry?
answerDescription: Pocahontas was captured and held for ransom by colonists during hostilities in 1613. During her captivity, she was "encouraged" to convert to Christianity and was baptized under the name Rebecca. She married tobacco planter John Rolfe in April 1614 at the age of 17 or 18 and bore him a son, Thomas Rolfe, in January 1615. The following year, the Rolfes traveled to London where Pocahontas was presented to English society as an example of the "civilized savage" in hopes of stimulating investment in the Jamestown settlement. She fell ill and died on the return voyage.

question: Which war claimed the lives of the most U.S. soldiers?
answerDescription: Until the Vietnam War, the number of U. S. soldiers killed in the American Civil War (approximately 620,000 casualties) surpassed all other wars combined.

question: Which vice president served under more than one president?
answerDescription: George Clinton, one of the Founding Fathers of the United States, served as vice president under both Thomas Jefferson (1805-1809) and James Madison (1809-1812).

question: Who was the only U.S. president to pay off the national debt?
answerDescription: On January 1, 1835, Andrew Jackson paid off the entire national debt, the only time in U.S. history that this has been accomplished. The objective had been reached in part through Jackson's reforms aimed at eliminating the misuse of funds and through his vetoes of legislation which he deemed extravagant.

question: What year was the first black woman elected to the U.S. Congress?
answerDescription: In 1968, Shirley Chisholm became the first black woman elected to the United States Congress, representing New York's 12th congressional district for seven terms from 1969 to 1983.

question: What mail service ran a route between Missouri and California from April 3, 1860, to October 24, 1861?
answerDescription: Operated by Central Overland California and Pikes Peak Express Company, the Pony Express was of great financial importance to the U.S. During its 18 months of operation, reducing the time for messages to travel between the Atlantic and Pacific coasts to about 10 days. It was not a financial success, however, and went bankrupt when faster telegraph service was established.

question: How old was the youngest American serviceman in World War II?
answerDescription: 12-year-old Calvin Graham lied about his age when he enlisted in the U.S. Navy in 1942. His real age wasn't discovered until after he was wounded in the Naval Battle of Guadalcanal.

question: Who was the first African-American president of the United States?
answerDescription: Barack Obama served as the 44th president of the United States from 2009 to 2017. He was born to an American mother of European descent and an African father from Kenya. Obama was born in Honolulu, Hawaii, making him the first president not born in the contiguous United States.

question: Where did the U.S. conduct most of its nuclear weapons tests in the 1950s?
answerDescription: From 1951 to 1992, as part of the nuclear arms race, a swath of land about 65 miles northwest of Las Vegas, Nevada was used for hundreds of nuclear weapons tests.

question: Which of the following was a U.S. policy opposing European colonialism in the Americas?
answerDescription: President James Monroe first stated the Monroe Doctrine during his seventh annual State of the Union Address to Congress. It stated that further efforts by European nations to take control of any independent state in North or South America would be viewed as "the manifestation of an unfriendly disposition toward the United States."

question: What was the name of the first African-American military aviators in the United States Armed Forces?
answerDescription: The Tuskegee Airmen were a group of primarily African-American military pilots who fought in World War II. In all, 992 pilots were trained in Tuskegee, Alabama from 1941 to 1946. Contrary to negative predictions from some quarters, the Tuskegee Airmen were some of the best pilots in the U.S. Army due to a combination of pre-war experience and the personal drive of those accepted for training, and after segregation in the military was ended in 1948 by President Harry S. Truman, the veteran Tuskegee Airmen found themselves in high demand throughout the newly formed United States Air Force.

question: Who designed the 50-star pattern on the U.S. flag?
answerDescription: When Alaska and Hawaii were being considered for statehood in the 1950s, more than 1,500 designs were submitted to President Dwight D. Eisenhower. Of these proposals, one created by 17-year-old Robert G. Heft in 1958 as a school project received the most publicity. His mother was a seamstress, but refused to do any of the work for him. He originally received a B- for the project. After discussing the grade with his teacher, it was agreed that if the flag was accepted by Congress, the grade would be reconsidered. Heft's flag design was chosen and adopted by presidential proclamation in 1959. Heft's teacher kept their agreement and changed his grade to an A.

question: What incident in 1962 nearly led to a nuclear confrontation between the U.S. and Russia?
answerDescription: On October 22, 1962, the Cuban Missile Crisis began when U.S. President John F. Kennedy announced that the Soviet Union was building a secret missile base in Cuba, just 90 miles off the coast of Florida. Hoping to avoid an armed invasion of Cuba, Kennedy opted for a naval quarantine of the island and demanded that Russian Premier Nikita Khrushchev remove all weapons. In response to the blockade, Khrushchev authorized his field commanders to launch nuclear weapons if attacked by U.S. forces. The two nations remained deadlocked for seven days before Khrushchev reconsidered and gave in to Kennedy's demands.

question: What series of anti-government protests and uprisings spread across much of the Arab world in the early 2010s?
answerDescription: The Arab Spring began in response to oppressive regimes and a low standard of living, starting with protests in Tunisia.

question: What year did women receive the right to vote in the United States?
answerDescription: In 1920, the 19th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution finally gave women the right to vote. It had been a long and hard fought battle, with many generations of supporters for women's suffrage lecturing, lobbying, and practicing civil disobedience to achieve what many Americans, at the time, considered a radical change to the Constitution.

question: What body of water was contaminated when the Deepwater Horizon oil rig exploded on April 20, 2010?
answerDescription: The Deepwater Horizon oil spill, which leaked 4.9 million barrels (210 million US gal; 780,000 m3) into the Gulf of Mexico, was one of the worst environmental disasters in U.S. history.

question: What year did the first man walk on the Moon?
answerDescription: On July 20 (July 21 GMT), 1969, American astronaut Neil Armstrong became the first man to walk on the Moon. As he stepped onto the Moon's surface, in the Sea of Tranquility, Armstrong uttered the now-famous words: "That's one small step for man; one giant leap for mankind."

question: What nation exploded its first nuclear bomb in the Rajasthan Desert in 1974?
answerDescription: On May 18, 1974, India exploded its first nuclear bomb in the Rajasthan Desert near the town of Pokhran, describing the event as a "peaceful nuclear explosion." According to various reports, the underground test produced a crater with a radius somewhere between 47 and 75 meters.

question: What year did the United States elect its first female vice-president?
answerDescription: On November 3, 2020, Kamala Harris made history as the first female, first black and first Asian-American US vice-president.

question: Where did the COVID-19 pandemic begin?
answerDescription: It was first identified in December 2019 in Wuhan, China. The World Health Organization declared the outbreak a Public Health Emergency of International Concern in January 2020 and a pandemic in March 2020. As of 27 January 2021, more than 100 million cases had been confirmed, with more than 2.16 million deaths attributed to COVID-19.

question: What U.S. President gave the White House its current name?
answerDescription: Although construction began in 1792, it was not until 1901 that President Theodore Roosevelt officially gave the White House its current name. Previously, it had been known as the "President's House," the "President's Palace," and the "Executive Mansion."

question: What year did scientists complete a map of the human genome?
answerDescription: In June of 2000, scientists at Celera Genomics announced that they had completed the first map of the human genome. This accomplishment was immediately recognized as one of the greatest achievements in scientific history. A more complete map was released in April of 2003.

question: What country launched the first artificial Earth satellite in 1957?
answerDescription: The launch of the Sputnik 1 satellite by the Soviet Union on October 4, 1957, started a Cold War technological and ideological competition with the United States known as the Space Race. The demonstration of American technological inferiority came as a profound shock to the American public. The Soviets followed up with Sputnik 2, which carried Laika, a Soviet space dog.

question: What Michigan city's water supply was contaminated with lead in 2014?
answerDescription: In April 2014, Flint changed its water source from treated Detroit Water and Sewerage Department water (sourced from Lake Huron and the Detroit River) to the Flint River. Officials failed to apply corrosion inhibitors to the water. As a result, lead from aging pipes leached into the water supply, leading to extremely elevated levels of the heavy metal neurotoxin and exposing over 100,000 residents to elevated lead levels. The city switched back to the Detroit water system on October 16, 2015.

question: June 6, 1944, is better known as what?
answerDescription: On June 6, 1944, the Invasion of Normandy began as U.S., British, and Canadian forces set out to liberate Europe from Nazi control. It was the largest air, land, and sea operation ever undertaken, involving more than 5,000 ships, 11,000 airplanes, and 150,000 soldiers. When the dust cleared, Allied Forces had suffered almost 10,000 casualties but the German lines had been breached and the defeat of Hitler was in sight. The success of D-Day was absolutely essential to Allied victory in World War II.

question: What toy was introduced in Australian stores in 1957 after proving to be a popular exercise tool in schools?
answerDescription: Wham-O, a fledgling California toy manufacturer, soon took notice of the Australian Hula Hoop craze and began selling plastic hoops in the United States. Within four months, twenty-five million Hula Hoops had been sold!

question: In 2013, two bombs exploded near the finish line of what famous race?
answerDescription: On April 15, 2013, two homemade pressure cooker bombs detonated 14 seconds apart near the finish line of the Boston Marathon, killing 3 people and injuring hundreds of others. One suspect was run over by his brother while trying to escape in a stolen car. The other was convicted of 30 charges, including use of a weapon of mass destruction.

question: Who tried to assassinate Ronald Reagan on March 30, 1981?
answerDescription: The shooter, John Hinckley Jr., was later found not guilty by reason of insanity. Public outcry over the verdict led to the Insanity Defense Reform Act of 1984, which altered the rules for consideration of mental illness of defendants in Federal Criminal Court proceedings in the United States.

question: What pseudonym was given to the secret informant who provided key details about U.S. president Richard Nixon's involvement in the Watergate scandal?
answerDescription: "Deep Throat" was first introduced to the public in the February 1974 book All the President's Men by Washington Post reporters Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein. He was a key source of information behind a series of articles that eventually led to the resignation of President Nixon, as well as to prison terms for several members of his White House staff.

question: What music festival was held August 15-18, 1969, on Max Yasgur's dairy farm in Bethel, New York?
answerDescription: Billed as "An Aquarian Experience: 3 Days of Peace and Music," the concert was expected to draw 50,000 attendees, but instead drew an estimated 500,000, most of whom crashed the concert without paying. The epic event would later be known simply as Woodstock and become synonymous with the counterculture movement of the 1960s.

question: What player broke the color barrier in Major League Baseball?
answerDescription: When the Brooklyn Dodgers signed Jackie Robinson in 1941, it heralded the end of racial segregation in professional baseball that had relegated black players to the Negro leagues since the 1880s. During his 10-year MLB career, Robinson won the inaugural Rookie of the Year Award in 1947, was an All-Star for six consecutive seasons from 1949 through 1954, and won the National League Most Valuable Player Award in 1949--the first black player so honored. He also played in six World Series, contributing to the Dodgers' 1955 World Series championship, and was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1962.

question: In 1849, Elizabeth Blackwell became the first female _______?
answerDescription: Rejected by all the leading schools because of her sex, Blackwell applied to Geneva Medical College where her application was accepted only after being endorsed by the current students who thought it was a joke. Through hard work and dedication, however, she earned the respect of her classmates and graduated first in her class on January 23, 1849. After running a private practice for many years, Elizabeth opened a Women's Medical College to help other women achieve the dream of becoming a doctor.

question: What famous painting was stolen from a Norwegian museum in 2004?
answerDescription: On August 22, 2004, two armed robbers stole "The Scream," a famous painting by Edvard Munch, from the Munch Museum in Norway. They also escaped with another Munch painting entitled "The Madonna." The museum estimated that the two stolen paintings were worth approximately $19 million (£10.4 million). On March 7, 2005, three more works by Munch were stolen from a hotel in Norway: a 1915 watercolor entitled "Blue Dress" and two lithographs including a self-portrait of the artist. Authorities did not know if the two robberies were related.

question: What supercomputer defeated World Chess Champion Garry Kasparov in 1997?
answerDescription: Kasparov found that he was no match for IBM's Deep Blue supercomputer, becoming the first world champion to lose a match to a computer under standard time controls. After the loss, Kasparov said that he detected a deep intelligence and creativity in the machine's moves, suggesting that human chess players had intervened. IBM denied that it cheated, saying the only human intervention occurred between games, when programmers were allowed to shore up weaknesses in the computer's play revealed during the course of the match. Years later, it was suggested that the behavior Kasparov noted may have resulted from a glitch in Deep Blue's program.

question: What toy sold 200 million units between 1980 and 1983?
answerDescription: Although the Rubik's Cube reached its height of mainstream popularity in the 1980s, it is still sold today and is widely considered to be the world's best-selling toy.

question: What Russian dancer defected to the U.S. in 1974?
answerDescription: Mikhail Baryshnikov, the preeminent male classical dancer of the 1970s and 1980s, never returned to Russia after his 1974 defection. He became a naturalized citizen of America in 1986.

question: What sparked the 1992 Los Angeles riots?
answerDescription: On March 3, 1991, Rodney King was beaten by LAPD officers after a high-speed chase during his arrest for drunk driving. A witness, George Holliday, filmed the incident from his nearby balcony and sent the footage to local news station KTLA. The footage showed an unarmed King on the ground being beaten and jolted with a 50,000-volt stun gun. Four officers were eventually tried on charges of use of excessive force. Of these, three were acquitted, and the jury failed to reach a verdict on one charge for the fourth. Within hours of the acquittals, the 1992 Los Angeles riots started, sparked by outrage among racial minorities over the trial's verdict.

question: What medical procedure was first performed in 1967?
answerDescription: Not having a human donor heart available, James D. Hardy of the University of Mississippi Medical Center transplanted the heart of a chimpanzee into the chest of dying Boyd Rush in the early morning of Jan. 24, 1964. Hardy used a defibrillator to shock the heart to restart beating, which it did for 60 to 90 minutes before Rush died without regaining consciousness.

question: What New Mexico town was the site of a famous UFO sighting in 1947?
answerDescription: The Roswell UFO incident, which involved a United States Army Air Forces balloon crash at a ranch near Roswell, New Mexico, has been described as "the world's most famous, most exhaustively investigated, and most thoroughly debunked UFO claim."

question: How many stars were added to the U.S. flag in 1959?
answerDescription: Alaska was admitted to the union on January 3, 1959, and Hawaii followed on August 21.

question: What gas is used to "turbo" cars in The Fast and the Furious?
answerDescription: A nitrous oxide engine is an internal combustion engine in which oxygen for burning the fuel comes from the decomposition of nitrous oxide, N2O, rather than air. The system increases the engine's power output by allowing fuel to be burned at a higher-than-normal rate. In The Fast and the Furious, this gas is commonly referred to as "nitrous" or simply NOS.

question: How many people does John Wick kill John Wick?
answerDescription: In John Wick, he kills 77 people, but he's just getting started. In John Wick: Chapter 2, he easily tops that with a body count of 128.

question: Where does Vernita Green hide her gun in Kill Bill: Volume 1?
answerDescription: Vernita tries to surprise the Bride with a pistol hidden in a box of cereal, but the Bride hurls a knife into Vernita's chest.

question: Which film features a fight scene in which Bruce Lee breaks Jackie Chan's neck?
answerDescription: Jackie Chan makes an uncredited cameo appearance towards the end of Enter the Dragon in the big fight scene in the cave. Bruce Lee grabs his hair and breaks his neck.

question: In Run Lola Run, how long does the title character have to obtain 100,000 Deutschmarks to save her boyfriend's life?
answerDescription: Lola receives a frantic phone call from her boyfriend Manni, a bagman responsible for delivering 100,000 Deutschmarks, which he has lost. Manni is meeting his boss in 20 minutes and will be killed unless he has the money.

question: What does John McClane write on the first terrorist he kills in Die Hard?
answerDescription: John puts a Santa hat on the corpse, sits him on a chair and uses a red permanent marker to write: "Now I have a machine gun. Ho Ho Ho."

question: In Colombiana, what "signature" does Cataleya leave behind after each of her assassinations?
answerDescription: With each murder she commits, she leaves her signature, the Cattleya flower, which is a message to her ultimate target, Don Luis, that she is coming for him.

question: How does Major William Cage die (the first time
options: BLOWS HIMSELF UP WITH A GRENADE
answerDescription: Cage uses a Claymore mine to kill an unusually large blue alien, but dies brutally when the alien's blood dissolves him.

question: When the sheriff pats him down in First Blood and finds his knife, what does Rambo say it's for?
answerDescription: SHERIFF: Why would you be carrying a knife like this?RAMBO: Hunting.SHERIFF: Don't be a wise guy! What do you hunt with a knife?RAMBO: Name it.

question: Who saves Grant, Ellie, and Hammond's grandchildren when they are cornered by Velociraptors at the end of Jurassic Park?
answerDescription: When all hope is lost, the T. Rex comes crashing into the atrium and attacks the raptors, buying enough time for everyone to escape.

question: What kind of "muttations" do the Gamemakers release to intensify the final moments of The Hunger Games?
answerDescription: As the Hunger Games draw to a close, the Head Gamemaker releases a pack of wolf-like "muttations" on the final tributes. Eerily, each of the mutts resembles one of the tributes who has died.

question: Where does Jack's compass point in Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl?
answerDescription: Although it appears to be nothing more than a useless trinket, Jack's compass, which he bartered from the voodoo mystic Tia Dalma, points to whatever he desires most.

question: How old is the ruthless vigilante Hit-Girl in Kick-Ass (2010
answerDescription: Big Daddy (Nicolas Cage) is a former cop who, in his quest to bring down the crime boss Frank D'Amico and his son Red Mist, has trained his eleven-year-old daughter (Chloë Grace Moretz) to be the ruthless vigilante Hit-Girl.

question: When Jackie Chan's foot catches on fire in The Legend of Drunken Master, how does he put it out?
answerDescription: When Wong (Jackie Chan) presses his foot against a red-hot vat while pushing off an assailant, his foot catches on fire. He puts it out by kicking at water thrown from a bucket by one of his friends.

question: Where does Sucker Punch (2011
answerDescription: The film stars Emily Browning as "Babydoll," a young woman who is committed to a mental institution and copes by envisioning it as a brothel. She teams up with four dancers/prisoners to escape before her scheduled lobotomy.

question: What shows the crew of the Black Pearl as they really are in Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl?
answerDescription: The crew has been cursed and become undead. Moonlight reveals them to be living, rotting skeletons.

question: What kind of samurai does Gisaku advise the villagers to hire in Seven Samurai?
answerDescription: Since they have no money and can only offer food as payment, Gisaku advises them to find hungry samurai.

question: How much does Rhett bid to dance with Scarlett in Gone With the Wind?
answerDescription: Rhett shocks the audience into silence by bidding $150 "in gold" for Scarlett as a dancing partner. Because she is in mourning, Rhett is told that it wouldn't be proper. But Scarlett scandalously accepts.

question: Which building does Kong scale in King Kong (1933
answerDescription: After Fay Wray's death in 2004, the Empire State Building memorialized the actress by briefly dimming its lights in honor of her legendary climb with Kong.

question: Which character attempts suicide in Citizen Kane?
answerDescription: After Susan attempts suicide, Kane releases her from her disastrous operatic career and retires to Xanadu.

question: What song does Ilsa ask Sam to play in Casablanca?
answerDescription: When Ilsa, Rick's former lover, spots Sam in the nightclub, she asks him to play "As Time Goes By." Rick storms over, furious that Sam has disobeyed his order never to perform the song, and is stunned to see Ilsa.

question: What is the name of Margo Channing's Broadway play in All About Eve?
answerDescription: When Margo misses a performance of Aged in Wood, her devious young understudy plots to steal her career.

question: In which film did John Wayne first play U.S. Marshall Rooster Cogburn?
answerDescription: Wayne won his only Oscar for his performance in True Grit and reprised his role for the 1975 sequel Rooster Cogburn.

question: Where does Paul get the ring he gives Holly in Breakfast at Tiffany's?
answerDescription: Although the ring is engraved at Tiffany's, he gets it out of a Crackerjack box.

question: The musical score for Psycho consists entirely of _____.
answerDescription: Despite Hitchcock's initial plan to use jazz, Bernard Herrmann's immortal Psycho score contains only stringed instruments.

question: Which film follows three U.S. Army soldiers, played by Burt Lancaster, Montgomery Clift, and Frank Sinatra, stationed on Hawaii in the months leading up to the attack on Pearl Harbor?
answerDescription: The film's title comes from Rudyard Kipling's 1892 poem "Gentlemen-Rankers" about soldiers of the British Empire who had lost their way and were "damned from here to eternity".

question: How many village girls does the tribal chief offer for Ann in King Kong (1933
answerDescription: When he sees Ann, the chief offers to trade six of his tribal women for the "golden woman". The crew rebuffs him, but that night the natives kidnap Ann from the ship and tie her to an altar as an offering to Kong.

question: In The Wizard of Oz, why does Miss Gulch take Toto?
options: DOROTHY DOESN'T HAVE A DOG LICENSE
answerDescription: Dorothy tries to convince her aunt and uncle that Toto didn't bite Miss Gulch, but the old witch has an order from the sheriff.

question: In Frankenstein (1931
answerDescription: When the monster encounters Maria, a young girl, she is not afraid and asks him to play a game with her. They toss flowers into a lake and watch them float. The Monster enjoys the game, but when they run out of flowers he thinks Maria will float as well, so he throws her into the lake. To his surprise, she disappears beneath the surface.

question: Which character in The Godfather is known as "The Turk"?
answerDescription: Rival racketeer Virgil Sollozzo is known as "The Turk" because he owns poppy fields in Turkey.

question: In Rebel Without a Cause, which character dies in a "Chickie Run"?
answerDescription: Buzz plunges to his death when the strap on his jacket sleeve becomes entangled with his door-latch lever, preventing him from exiting the car in time.

question: What is the only Disney animated feature film that has a title character who doesn't speak?
answerDescription: Dumbo doesn't utter a single word during the movie.

question: What popular Disney character makes a cameo appearance as a stuffed animal in Frozen?
answerDescription: Micky Mouse made a special appearance in Wandering Oaken's Trading Post and Sauna--in the form of a plush toy.

question: What does the little mermaid call the fork in her collection of human objects?
answerDescription: Ariel displays the dinglehopper proudly in her undersea grotto.

question: What was the only character in Disney's Alice in Wonderland that did not appear in Lewis Carroll's books?
answerDescription: The Doorknob was also one of the few characters in Wonderland to show any sympathy for Alice.

question: Who was the first Disney princess?
answerDescription: Although Snow White was Disney's first full-length movie princess, she wasn't the first Disney princess. That honor goes to Persephone, the main character of a 1934 Silly Symphonies short that served as a sort of test run for Snow White.

question: What is the name of the pub that Flynn brings Rapunzel to in Tangled?
answerDescription: The Snuggly Duckling is a pub located somewhere in the woods, not too far from Rapunzel's tower, where all the local ruffians like to hang out.

question: What is Boo's real name in Monster's Inc.?
answerDescription: Although her real name is never spoken out loud, she signs some of her drawings "Mary".

question: What is Monstro in Pinocchio?
answerDescription: Monstro is a massive whale with a fearsome reputation among sailors and sea creatures alike. He swallows Geppetto, Figaro, and Cleo when they take to the sea in search of Pinocchio.

question: How many eggs does Gaston eat for breakfast?
answerDescription: When he was a lad, he ate four dozen eggs every morning to help him get large. And now that he's grown, he eats five dozen eggs, so he's roughly the size of a barge!

question: What time does the royal ball start in Cinderella?
answerDescription: According to the bell tower in Cinderella, the royal ball starts at 8pm.

question: Which character in Frozen likes warm hugs?
answerDescription: Created from Elsa's magical powers, Olaf is the friendliest snowman in Arendelle. He is innocent, outgoing and likes warm hugs.

question: What was the first Disney animated film to feature a completely original storyline?
answerDescription: The Lion King was billed as Disney's first animated feature that wasn't a retelling of another story or fairytale.

question: What flavor is Jane's medicine in Mary Poppins?
answerDescription: Jane's lime cordial is "Delicious!" Michael's strawberry flavor is downed with a satisfied "Mmmmm." And Mary Poppins finds her rum punch "Quite satisfactory."

question: Where is the entrance to Peter Pan's hideout?
answerDescription: The Hangman's Tree is an old tree, located deep within Neverland, with several hidden entrances that Peter and the Lost Boys use to enter and exit their hideout.

question: What does Timothy Q. Mouse have under his hat when he first meets Dumbo?
answerDescription: Timothy uses the peanut to coax Dumbo out from under the hay in which he is hiding after being mistreated by the other elephants.

question: Some scenes of woodland creatures and the forest fire in Bambi are actually unused footage from what other Disney movie?
answerDescription: Some scenes of woodland creatures and the forest fire in Bambi (1942) are unused footage from Pinocchio (1940).

question: What actor provided the voice of Hercules in the Spanish language version of the Disney film?
answerDescription: In the Spanish language version, the voice of Hercules is played by Ricky Martin and Megara is voiced by singer Tatiana.

question: In Sleeping Beauty, the cookies that the fairies eat with tea are shaped like what?
answerDescription: The cookies that the fairies eat with their tea are shaped like Mickey Mouse's head and ears.

question: In The Little Mermaid, what name does Ursula go by when she disguises herself as a human to steal Eric from Ariel?
answerDescription: When Ariel comes too close to succeeding in her task, the sea witch decides to take matters into her own tentacles. She takes the form of a beautiful woman named "Vanessa" and uses Ariel's own voice to sabotage her relationship with Eric.

question: Which Disney princess wears pants instead of a dress?
answerDescription: Princess Jasmine's everyday outfit consists of a cropped off-the-shoulder top and matching aqua pants.

question: What was Walt Disney's favorite song from Mary Poppins?
answerDescription: "Feed the Birds" was not only Walt's favorite song from the movie--but his favorite song ever. According to Richard Sherman (One of the songwriters behind the song), Walt would stop by the Sherman Brothers office every Friday and request a private performance.

question: Where does Aladdin live?
answerDescription: Agrabah was actually a stand-in for Baghdad, the city that Disney originally planned to be the movie's setting, before changing the name due to political issues that were occurring at the time.

question: What kind of pet does Maleficent have in Sleeping Beauty?
answerDescription: Her pet raven Diablo is the only thing Maleficent genuinely cares about. She is visibly shaken when she finds him turned to stone.

question: What is Bambi's first word?
answerDescription: Thumper teaches Bambi how to speak. His first word is "bird".

question: What is the name of Snow White's prince?
answerDescription: Trick question! Although his name isn't actually mentioned in the film, he is occasionally referred to as Prince Florian for Disney on Ice shows.

question: What is the name of Cinderella's wicked stepmother?
answerDescription: Unlike most Disney villains, who sport fiery personalities and desire power and the spotlight, Lady Tremaine possesses a more cunning, subtle, passive-aggressive personality with a shrewd intelligence and ability for manipulation, particularly towards her daughters.

question: Who was the first Disney princess with a tattoo?
answerDescription: Pocahontas was the first Disney princess with a visible tattoo, a red armband around her right bicep.

question: In The Lion King, what is Simba's mother's name?
answerDescription: Sarabi is first seen with the infant Simba, at Simba's presentation, and watches as the sun shines down upon the new prince and illuminates the kingdom. She later makes an appearance when an excited Simba awakens his parents before dawn. She wryly tells Mufasa that his son is awake, while Mufasa responds that Simba is Sarabi's son before sunrise.

question: What is Sven's favorite snack in Frozen?
answerDescription: Sven's favorite snacks are carrots and lichen. He takes an immediate liking to Olaf the snowman because of his carrot nose.

question: Which Disney film features the song "Higitus Figitus"?
answerDescription: "Higitus Figitus" is from The Sword in the Stone (1963). It is sung by Merlin as he packs his things.

question: What is the name of Prince Phillip's horse in Sleeping Beauty?
answerDescription: Samson and Phillip are out riding when Phillip is enchanted by Aurora's beautiful voice and sets out to investigate. Samson is initially against the idea, but Phillip convinces him to go along with the promise of an extra bag of oats.

question: What baby animal does Moana rescue as a toddler?
answerDescription: Moana finds a baby sea turtle hiding under a tree from the frigatebirds. The turtle, which bears an uncanny resemblance to Squirt from Finding Nemo, is frightened and tries to hide in its shell. Moana sees it and breaks a leaf off the tree, then holds it over the sea turtle, helping it into the water.

question: Which family member do the Madrigals refuse to talk about in Encanto?
answerDescription: Vilified and scapegoated for his gift of precognition, Bruno disappeared ten years before the start of the film and is insinuated to be villainous. "We Don't Talk About Bruno" is one of Encanto's biggest musical hits and the longest-reigning chart-topper for Disney in the US Billboard Hot 100 history.

question: In Mulan, what type of animal perches on the shoulder of the villain Shan Yu?
answerDescription: Hayabusa is Shan Yu's pet falcon. The bird often acts as a warning signal, alerting victims that Shan Yu is near.

question: In Peter Pan, Which of the Darling children wears a tophat?
answerDescription: John Darling wears glasses, a long nightshirt, a top hat, and carries an umbrella.

question: At the end of 101 Dalmations, Roger and Anita decide to move to a Dalmation _______.
answerDescription: After counting 84 extra puppies, they decide to keep all the puppies and use the money from Roger's new hit song to buy a larger house in the country so they can have a Dalmatian plantation.

question: In Alice in Wonderland, what is the name of Alice's pet kitten?
answerDescription: When Alice falls down the rabbit hole, she waves goodbye to Dinah who almost falls down the hole after her.

question: Which Disney princess has a racoon for a sidekick?
answerDescription: Meeko the racoon loves food, especially John Smith's biscuits.

question: How many "thingamabobs" does the little mermaid have?
answerDescription: I've got gadgets and gizmos aplentyI've got whozits and whatzits galore(You want thingamabobs? I got twenty)But who cares?No big dealI want more

question: In Aladdin, what is Jafar's last wish?
answerDescription: Aladdin tricks Jafar into using his last wish to become an all-powerful genie, which includes being trapped inside his own magic lamp.

question: What does Aunt Sarah buy for Lady in Lady and the Tramp?
answerDescription: Aunt Sarah's two trouble-making Siamese cats deliberately mess up the house and trick her into thinking that Lady attacked them. Aunt Sarah then takes Lady to a pet shop to get a muzzle.

question: What evil spirits attack Kumandra in Raya and the Last Dragon?
answerDescription: Kumandra is ravaged by the Druun, evil spirits that attack and petrify the land's people and dragons.

question: Which character remarks that Bambi is "kinda wobbly"?
answerDescription: Thumper is reprimanded by his mother for the remark. She makes him repeat what his father has impressed upon him this morning, "If you can't say somethin' nice, don't say nothin' at all".

question: In Beauty and the Beast, which character does Lumière have a romantic relationship with?
answerDescription: Lumière is frequently seen flirting with the feather duster.

question: What do the Kakamora wear as armor?
answerDescription: The Kakamora are a savage tribe of coconut-armored pirates who seek the heart of Te Fiti, but Moana and Maui outwit them.

question: Which Disney character was voiced by a war hero?
answerDescription: Before he became a decorated Vietnam War veteran in the Marines, receiving a Bronze Star and three Purple Hearts for his service, Donnie Dunagan was a child actor. The most famous role in his short career was Bambi in the 1942 Disney classic.

question: Where was Cinderella's bedroom?
answerDescription: After her father died, Cinderella was forced to live in the attic.

question: Which nanny preceded Mary Poppins at the Banks home?
answerDescription: George Banks returns home to learn from his wife that Katie Nanna has left their service after Jane and Michael ran her off again.

question: Dumbo was the first Disney animated feature ________.
options: WITH A PROTAGONIST THAT DOESN'T SPEAK
answerDescription: In addition to the American setting, Dumbo was the first Disney animated feature film to be set in the present time of its release (1941) and to feature a protagonist with no spoken dialogue.

question: Who disguises himself as an orangutan to rescue Mowgli in The Jungle Book?
answerDescription: Baloo dresses as a female orangutan and dances with King Louie.

question: Mulan is the first Disney princess _______.
options: TO NOT SING ABOUT HER LOVE FOR A HERO
TO BE SEEN GETTING A HAIRCUT
answerDescription: Unlike previous Disney princesses, Mulan is visibly wounded, gets a haircut onscreen, and does NOT sing about her love for a hero.

question: What classic horror movie features a serial killer in a William Shatner mask?
answerDescription: Due to its shoestring budget, the prop department for Halloween (1978) had to use the cheapest mask that they could find in the costume store: a William Shatner mask from The Devil's Rain (1975), which they altered by spray-painting the face white and reshaping the eyeholes.

question: In which horror movie does the protagonist write a book that contains only the line "All work and no play makes Jack a dull boy" repeated over and over and over?
answerDescription: The book that Jack writes in The Shining contains only the one sentence ("All work and no play makes Jack a dull boy") repeated over and over. Director Stanley Kubrick had each page individually typed.

question: What classic horror movie was originally titled The Babysitter Murders?
answerDescription: Director John Carpenter originally intended to call his movie The Babysitter Murders, but producer Irwin Yablans thought the story might resonate more if it were based around a specific holiday, so the title was changed to Halloween.

question: How many people associated with The Exorcist died during production?
answerDescription: By the end of the film's production, nine people associated with its making had passed away, including Jack McGowran who played Burke Dennings, Linda Blair's grandfather, a night watchman on set, and a special effects expert.

question: What horror film was the first movie to show a woman in just a bra and slip?
answerDescription:
In the opening scene of Psycho,
Marion Crane (played by Janet Leigh) wears only a white bra and half-slip, having just had a mid-day tryst with her divorced lover in a hotel. While the scene leaves much to the modern imagination, in 1960 it was shockingly direct.

question: What color is Freddy Krueger's sweater?
answerDescription: Craven chose to make Krueger's sweater red and green after reading an article in a 1982 Scientific American that said these two colors were the most clashing colors to the human retina.

question: How many people does Jason kill in the first Friday the 13th film?
answerDescription: In the first movie, Jason's mother Pamela does the killing.

question: In Scream, what is Rule #1 on Randy's list of rules for surviving a horror movie?
answerDescription: Scream itself subverts the idea that sex marks a character for certain death when Sidney sleeps with Billy who turns out to be one of the killers.

question: What horror movie required the purchase of 500 Florida frogs and 100 giant South American toads?
answerDescription: Many of the 500 Florida frogs and 100 giant South American toads purchased for use in The Frogs escaped during production.

question: What horror movie features a serial killer wearing a mask inspired by an Edvard Munch painting?
options: THE MAN IN THE BLACK SUIT
HENRY: PORTRAIT OF A SERIAL KILLER
answerDescription: The mask in Scream is based on an Edvard Munch painting entitled "The Scream."

question: What horror film caused some theatres to suggest that patrons prone to motion sickness sit in the aisle seats?
answerDescription: Some theatergoers watching The Blair Witch Project experienced nausea from the handheld camera movements and actually had to leave to vomit. In some Toronto theatres, ushers asked patrons who where prone to motion sickness to sit in the aisle seat and to try not to "throw up on other people."

question: In Poltergeist, what grabs Robbie Freeling through his bedroom window?
answerDescription: The Freelings built their house next to a big oak tree. Steven tells his son Robbie that he built the house next to the tree so it could protect them, claiming that it is a "very wise old tree". But the tree comes to life during a thunderstorm, smashing through the wall and abducting Robbie.

question: How much screen time does Freddy Krueger get in the first A Nightmare on Elm Street movie?
answerDescription: Director Wes Craven knew the unseen was far scarier than the seen, which is why Freddy Krueger only has 7 minutes of screen time in the original film.

question: Where does Friday the 13th take place?
answerDescription: Camp Crystal Lake had 22 years of uninterrupted good times until a handicapped camper drowned in the summer of 1957, setting off string of grisly murders.

question: Why can't Michael Myers be killed?
