answerDescription: The Second Continental Congress voted to approve a resolution of independence that had been proposed in June by Richard Henry Lee of Virginia declaring the United States independent from Great Britain rule.

question: On what day did Congress vote for American independence?
answerDescription: Although the Continental Congress declared independence on July 4, they actually voted to declare independence two days earlier, on July 2, 1776. John Adams would later write to his wife: "The second day of July, 1776, will be the most memorable epoch in the history of America.... It ought to be solemnized with pomp and parade, with shows, games, sports, guns, bells, bonfires, and illuminations, from one end of this continent to the other, from this time forward forever more."

question: Who was the principal author of the Declaration of Independence?
answerDescription: The Declaration of Independence was prepared by a Committee of Five, with Thomas Jefferson as its principal author.

question: Which newspaper first printed the Declaration of Independence?
answerDescription: On July 6, 1776, The Pennsylvania Evening Post, which was published every Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday, carried the Declaration on the front page.

question: In 1778, how did George Washington commemorate the Fourth of July?
options: A DAY OF FASTING AND PRAYER
THE BIRTH OF HIS FIRST CHILD
answerDescription: In 1778, from his headquarters at Ross Hall, near New Brunswick, New Jersey, General George Washington marked July 4 with a double ration of rum for his soldiers.

question: Who wrote the lyrics to "The Star-Spangled Banner"?
answerDescription: The lyrics were written on September 14, 1814, by amateur poet Francis Scott Key after witnessing the bombardment of Fort McHenry by British ships of the Royal Navy in Baltimore Harbor during the Battle of Baltimore in the War of 1812. Key was inspired by the large American flag flying triumphantly above the fort during the American victory.

question: On the original American flag, what shape were the thirteen stars arranged in?
answerDescription: The stars on the original flag were in a circle so all the Colonies would appear equal.

question: Which U.S. President first held a Fourth of July celebration at the White House?
answerDescription: Although John Adams was the first president to occupy the executive mansion, it was Thomas Jefferson who established the traditions of a July 4th celebration at the White House. On July 4, 1801, he opened the Executive Mansion to diplomats, civil and military officers and Cherokee chiefs.

question: How many hot dogs are consumed each 4th of July?
answerDescription: According to the National Hot Dog and Sausage Council, approximately 150 million hot dogs are consumed each Independence Day. That's enough dogs to stretch from Washington D.C. to Los Angeles more than five times!

question: Who was the only signer of the Declaration of Independence who later recanted his support for the document?
answerDescription: On November 30, 1776, Richard Stockton, a lawyer from Princeton, was captured by the British and thrown in jail. After months of harsh treatment and meager rations, Stockton repudiated his signature on the Declaration of Independence and swore his allegiance to King George III.

question: What was the first state to declare the 4th of July an official holiday?
answerDescription: On July 4, 1781, the Massachusetts General Court became the first state legislature to recognize July 4 as an official state celebration.

question: What year were fireworks first used in an official Fourth of July celebration?
answerDescription: Congress authorized using fireworks to help mark the first anniversary of the Declaration of Independence. The celebration, which took place in Philadelphia, also included bonfires and bells.

question: Which two U.S. Presidents died on July 4 in the same year?
answerDescription: Both John Adams and Thomas Jefferson, the only signers of the Declaration of Independence to later serve as Presidents of the United States, died on the same day: July 4, 1826, which was the 50th anniversary of the Declaration.

question: How many founding fathers signed the Declaration of Independence?
answerDescription: The Declaration of Independence was signed by 56 men from 13 colonies.

question: Which U.S. President was born on the Fourth of July?
answerDescription: Calvin Coolidge, the 30th President, was born on July 4, 1872.

question: What day was the Fourth of July celebrated in 1779?
answerDescription: In 1779, the 4th of July fell on a Sunday, so the celebrations were held on Monday, July 5.

question: Which U.S. President signed the bill that made "The Star Spangled Banner" the national anthem?
answerDescription: "The Star-Spangled Banner" was made the national anthem by a congressional resolution on March 3, 1931 and signed by President Herbert Hoover.

question: Who was NOT on the "Committee of Five" that drafted the Declaration of Independence?
answerDescription: On June 11, 1776, Congress appointed a "Committee of Five", consisting of John Adams of Massachusetts, Benjamin Franklin of Pennsylvania, Thomas Jefferson of Virginia, Robert R. Livingston of New York, and Roger Sherman of Connecticut, to draft the declaration.

question: What accounts for the most fireworks-related injuries every 4th of July?
answerDescription: Though sparklers and firecrackers seem innocent enough, they account for almost 40 percent of all fireworks related accidents.

question: Where is the nation's oldest Fourth of July parade?
answerDescription: The annual Fourth of July Parade in Bristol, Rhode Island was established in 1785 by Rev. Henry Wight of the First Congregational Church and veteran of the Revolutionary War.

question: What year did the 4th of July become a paid federal holiday?
answerDescription: On July 4, 1938, the United States Congress changed Independence Day to a paid federal holiday. It had previously been established as an unpaid federal holiday in 1870.

question: What happened on July 4, 1960?
options: DEADLY HEATWAVE KILLED HUNDREDS OF AMERICANS
answerDescription: A 50th star was added to the American flag to represent the new state of Hawaii.

question: What institution first opened its doors on July 4, 1802?
answerDescription: The United States Military Academy, also known as West Point, officially commenced operations on 4 July 1802.

question: Black Friday begins the day after which holiday?
answerDescription: The day after Thanksgiving has been regarded as the beginning of America's Christmas shopping season since the 1950s, although the term "Black Friday" didn't become widely used until more recent years.

question: The term Black Friday originated in what U.S. city?
answerDescription: Police officers in Philadelphia were first to link Black Friday to the post-Thanksgiving period in the 1950s. Large crowds of tourists and shoppers came to the city the day after Thanksgiving for the Army-Navy football game, creating chaos, traffic jams and shoplifting opportunities. Police officers in the city weren't able to take the day off work and instead had to work long shifts to control the carnage, coining the phrase Black Friday to refer to it.

question: Why is Black Friday black?
options: IT DRIVES SOME STORES OUT OF BUSINESS
answerDescription: Black Friday represents the point in the year when retailers begin to turn a profit, thus going from being "in the red" to being "in the black".

question: Which retailer is the most dangerous place to shop on Black Friday?
answerDescription: The most violence seems to occur at Walmart (57.1 percent of Black Friday incidents) leading to the Twitter hashtag each year #Walmartfights.

question: What did some merchants try to rename Black Friday?
answerDescription: As the name spread throughout Philadelphia in the 1950s, some of the city's merchants disliked the negative connotations and unsuccessfully tried to change it to "Big Friday".

question: What was the first department store to advertise a post-Thanksgiving sale?
answerDescription: The department store Macy's was the first to advertise post-Thanksgiving shopping in 1924, during their Thanksgiving Day Parade in New York.

question: What percent of Black Friday shoppers later regret their purchases?
answerDescription: An estimated 52% of shoppers purchase something on sale that they later regret.

question: What is the going rate for hiring someone to wait in line for you on Black Friday?
answerDescription: Professional line sitters make up to $35 an hour, and Black Friday is their busiest day of the year.

question: What is the Monday after Black Friday called?
answerDescription: The Monday after Thanksgiving was first given the name "Cyber Monday" in 2005 by Shop.org and has since become nearly as important to retailers as Black Friday.

question: What year did the term Black Friday first appear in The New York Times?
answerDescription: Use of the phrase spread slowly, first appearing in The New York Times on November 29, 1975, in which it still refers specifically to "the busiest shopping and traffic day of the year" in Philadelphia.

question: An advertisement in what magazine helped cement the term Black Friday in the American consciousness?
answerDescription: Word about Black Friday spread after an advertisement was published in The American Philatelist in 1966.

question: What percent of Black Friday shoppers have been drinking?
answerDescription: According to a survey conducted on behalf of the coupon site RetailMeNot, 12% of all Black Friday shoppers admit they hit the stores while under the influence of alcohol.

question: How many countries besides the U.S. have some form of Black Friday?
answerDescription: Today, at least 20 other countries observe some kind of late-November launch to the holiday shopping season.

question: What percent of Americans shop on Black Friday?
answerDescription: According to a National Retail Federation survey, 70% of Americans shopped in stores or online during Black Friday last year.

question: Which items are discounted the least on Black Friday?
answerDescription: According to a study from WalletHub market research, books, movies and music have the best bargain prices on Black Friday, while furniture and jewelry are discounted the least.

question: How much does the average Black Friday shopper spend?
answerDescription: A poll of 2,000 Americans found that the average American spends about $520 on Black Friday.

question: What year did Black Friday become the busiest shopping day of the year?
answerDescription: Black Friday has routinely been the busiest shopping day of the year in the United States since 2005.

question: What time does in-store foot traffic peak on Black Friday?
answerDescription: In-store traffic actually peaks at 4pm on Black Friday, not early in the morning.

question: What is Black Friday called in Mexico?
answerDescription: In Mexico, it is referred to as "El Buen Fin", which translates to "the good weekend".

question: Which U.S. state spends the most money per shopper on Black Friday?
answerDescription: Wisconsinites spend an average of $1,392.60 on Black Friday.

question: What year did retailers first open at midnight for Black Friday?
answerDescription: In 2011, several retailers (including Target, Kohl's, Macy's, Best Buy, and Bealls) opened at midnight for the first time.

question: Who are the biggest spenders on Black Friday?
answerDescription: According to The Washington Post, the biggest spenders are Millennials (those born between 1977 and 1995).

question: The real St. Nicholas was born in what modern-day country?
answerDescription: It is believed that the real St. Nicholas was born sometime around 280 A.D. in Patara, near Myra in modern-day Turkey. According to legend, his extraordinary kindness led him to give away all of his inherited wealth as he traveled the countryside helping the sick and poverty-stricken.

question: Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer was created as a promotion for what department store?
answerDescription: Montgomery Ward hired a writer named Robert L. May in 1939 to write a Christmas story which could be given away to holiday shoppers. May's brother-in-law, songwriter Johnny Marks, liked the story and decided to write a song to go with it. The resulting "Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer", eventually recorded in 1949 by Gene Autry, has become a Christmas classic.

question: What song does Lucy ask Schroeder to play on his piano in "A Charlie Brown Christmas"?
answerDescription: Schroeder attempts to play several complex versions of Jingle Bells for Lucy with her dismissing each one with a "No, no, no." He plunks out a single key version and she yells "That's it!"

question: In "The Twelve Days of Christmas", there are how many drummers drumming?
answerDescription: There are twelve drummers drumming. According to Catholic tradition, The twelve drummers symbolized the twelve points of belief in The Apostles' Creed.

question: Where was the baby Jesus born?
answerDescription: The New Testament identifies Bethlehem as the birthplace of the baby Jesus.

question: What was the name of the magician with the magic hat in the 1969 TV special "Frosty the Snowman"?
answerDescription: A washed-up magician named Professor Hinkle wants desperately to get his discarded magic hat back after he realizes that it has brought Frosty to life.

question: Eggnog was first consumed in what U.S. city?
answerDescription: According to the historical accounts of Captain John Smith, the first eggnog made in the United States was consumed in his 1607 Jamestown settlement. "Nog" was, apparently, a variation of the word "grog", which refers to any drink made with rum.

question: What English monarch established the Christmas tree tradition in Great Britain?
answerDescription: England didn't get on the Christmas tree bandwagon until 1848, when Queen Victoria set up a tree at Windsor Castle.

question: What is the name of Ebeneezer Scrooge's deceased business partner?
answerDescription: Jacob Marley is now a tormented spirit, forced to wander the earth forevermore as punishment for his greedy, selfish and uncaring attitude towards mankind.

question: Who tried to steal Christmas from the Whos of Whoville?
answerDescription: In How the Grinch Stole Christmas!, the Grinch attempts to put an end to Christmas by stealing presents from the homes of the nearby town Whoville on Christmas Eve. Despite his efforts, Whoville's inhabitants still celebrate the holiday, so the Grinch returns everything that he stole and is the guest of honor at the Whos' Christmas dinner.

question: Why were candy canes first invented?
answerDescription: The first candy cane was made in 1670 by a German choirmaster to help children endure lengthy nativity services. They were white and modeled after shepherds' canes to remind the children of the shepherds that visited baby Jesus at the first Christmas.

question: According to the Bible, how did Mary and Joseph get to Bethlehem?
answerDescription: Although most modern depictions of the journey show Mary riding a donkey, the Bible doesn't say!

question: Who narrated the classic 1966 TV special "How the Grinch Stole Christmas"?
answerDescription: Although Theodor Geisel (Dr. Seuss) originally disputed casting Boris Karloff for fear that he would make the Grinch too scary, it turned out to be a perfect match, and "How the Grinch Stole Christmas" became an instant classic.

question: In the 1965 TV special "A Charlie Brown Christmas", who builds a gray snowman?
answerDescription: The ever-filthy Pigpen can't keep his snow clean and builds a gray snowman.

question: In what country are outdoor barbecues a traditional part of Christmas festivities?
answerDescription: In Australia, Christmas comes in the middle of summer and the temperature often hits a sweltering 100 degrees Fahrenheit on Christmas day. During this warm Australian Christmas season, outdoor barbecues have become a part of the Christmas tradition.

question: In the classic 1964 TV special "Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer", what did Hermey the elf want to be?
answerDescription: Rudolph teams up with Hermey, an elf who wants to be a dentist. Together, they attempt to save an island of misfit toys.

question: Where was Mommy kissing Santa Claus?
answerDescription: "I saw Mommy kissing Santa Claus underneath the mistletoe last night."

question: What author wrote that it was "always winter but never Christmas"?
answerDescription: In the Chronicles of Narnia, C. S. Lewis wrote about the White Witch and how she cast a spell making it always winter but never Christmas.

question: What is Frosty the Snowman's nose made of?
answerDescription: "Frosty the snowman was a jolly happy soul / With a corncob pipe and a button nose / And two eyes made out of coal."

question: Good King Wenceslas was duke of what country?
answerDescription: The legend of Good King Wenceslas is based on the life of the historical Saint Wenceslaus I, Duke of Bohemia. His martyrdom and the popularity of several biographies gave rise to a reputation for heroic goodness that resulted in his elevation to sainthood.

question: In what country are Christmas trees decorated with spiders?
answerDescription: In traditional Ukrainian houses a Christmas tree will often be decorated with a spider and web for good luck.

question: What sort of fish do European families eat for Christmas dinner?
answerDescription: For centuries, families throughout much of central Europe have relied on one simple main course for Christmas Eve dinner: the common carp. Traditionally kept in the bathtub, the fish can become a sort of family pet for a day or two, before becoming dinner.

question: How does the Dutch version of Santa Claus transport his presents?
answerDescription: Dutch children have long cheered the annual coming of Sinterklaas--or Saint Nicholas--who arrives on a steamboat filled with presents in mid-November.

question: Which of the following gifts did the wise men NOT bring to the baby Jesus?
answerDescription: The wise men brought gold, frankincense and myyrh.

question: Where did the Grinch live?
answerDescription: Every Who Down in Whoville Liked Christmas a lot ...But the Grinch, who lived just north of Whoville, Did NOT!

question: In the TV special Santa Claus Is Comin' to Town (1970
answerDescription: Winter's last magical tool, his Magic Feed Corn, allows Santa's reindeer friends to fly.

question: What did roast turkey replace on the British royal family's Christmas Day menu?
answerDescription: Roast turkey did not appear consistently on royal Christmas Day menus until 1851 when it replaced roast swan.

question: Which Christmas song was banned by many American radio stations in 2018?
options: "GRANDMA GOT RUN OVER BY A REINDEER"
answerDescription: The 1944 Christmas tune "Baby, It's Cold Outside" was banned by radio stations across the country -- and even in Canada -- for its lyrics that some said were inappropriate in the wake of the #MeToo movement.

question: Which of the Beatles wrote "Happy Xmas (War Is Over
answerDescription: "Happy Xmas (War Is Over)" was the culmination of more than two years of peace activism undertaken by John Lennon and Yoko Ono that began with the bed-ins they convened in March and May 1969, the first of which took place during their honeymoon.

question: What color is Santa's belt?
answerDescription: Santa is traditionally depicted wearing a black belt with a gold buckle.

question: Who spoke to the little lamb in the Christmas carol "Do You Hear What I Hear?"
answerDescription: Said the night wind to the little lambDo you see what I seeWay up in the sky little lambDo you see what I seeA star, a starDancing in the nightWith a tail as big as a kiteWith a tail as big as a kite

question: The Japanese Christmas cake is what kind of cake?
answerDescription: Intertwined with Japan's rise from the ruins after its defeat in World War II, the traditional Christmas strawberry shortcake is now a symbol of commercialism and prosperity.

question: Which common type of Christmas tree is NOT edible?
answerDescription: Your Christmas tree might look better decked out in lights than it would on your plate, but all spruce, firs, and pines can be eaten. (Pine needles are an especially good source of vitamin C!) Yew trees, however, are extremely poisonous.

question: What did Tim Smith invent in 1847?
answerDescription: Christmas crackers--also known as bon-bons in some regions--consist of a segmented cardboard tube wrapped in a brightly decorated twist of paper with a prize in the central chamber. The cracker is pulled apart by two people, each holding an outer chamber, causing the cracker to split unevenly and leaving one person holding the central chamber and the prize.

question: The Chichilaki is a type of ____________.
answerDescription: The Chichilaki is a Georgian traditional Christmas tree made from dried hazelnut or walnut branches that are shaved to form a small coniferous tree. Georgians believe the Chichilaki resembles the famous beard of St. Basil the Great.

question: In the holiday romance Serendipity, what book does Sara write her phone number in?
options: LOVE IN THE TIME OF CHOLERA
answerDescription: Jonathan (John Cusack) and Sara (Kate Beckinsale) spend the evening together and feel a strong bond, but Sara insists that if it's really meant to be, they will find each other again. She writes her number in a copy of Love in the Time of Cholera, and leaves it up to Jonathan to find it.

question: What year was Santa's wife, Mrs. Claus, first introduced to the world?
answerDescription: Mrs. Claus was first introduced to the world in 1889 in the book Goody Santa Claus On A Sleigh Ride by the poet Katherine Lee Bates. In this story, Mrs. Claus pleads with Santa to take her along on the annual Christmas Eve sleigh ride to deliver toys to all the good little boys and girls. When Santa finds one little boy's stocking that is too tattered to hold presents, Mrs. Claus pops down the chimney and mends the stocking, saving the day.

question: Whose eyes are all aglow in "The Christmas Song"?
answerDescription: "Tiny tots with their eyes all aglow will find it hard to sleep tonight."

question: In Chile, how does Old Man Christmas enter homes?
answerDescription: In Chile, Old Man Christmas is said to enter homes through a window.

question: According to the popular song, what did a reindeer do to grandma?
answerDescription: According to Randy Brooks' "Grandma Got Run Over by a Reindeer", Grandma got run over by a reindeer, walking home from our house Christmas Eve.

question: What is the Chinese Santa Claus called?
answerDescription: China's Dun Che Lao Ren (Christmas Old Man) arrives during the Chinese Holy Birth Festival to fill children's stockings with gifts.

question: Who were the Magi?
answerDescription: The Magi were three Wise Men who visited Jesus after his birth, bearing gifts of gold, frankincense and myrrh.

question: What famous Christmas song was originally written for Thanksgiving?
answerDescription: "Jingle Bells" was originally composed for children to sing in a Boston Sunday School celebration. It was meant for the Thanksgiving season and had no connection to Christmas.

question: Who was seated next to me a day or two ago in the song "Jingle Bells"?
answerDescription: A day or two agoI thought I'd take a rideAnd soon Miss Fanny BrightWas seated by my side;The horse was lean and lank;Misfortune seemed his lot;He got into a drifted bankAnd we, we got upsot!

question: What did General Sherman give Abraham Lincoln for Christmas in 1864?
answerDescription: After capturing the city in his famous March to the Sea from Atlanta, General Sherman sent President Lincoln a telegram saying, "I beg to present to you as a Christmas gift the city of Savannah."

question: In the song "Winter Wonderland", who do they pretend the snowman is?
answerDescription: In the meadow we can build a snowmanThen pretend that he is Parson Brown

question: What color is snoopy's doghouse in A Charlie Brown Christmas?
answerDescription: Snoopy's dog house is blue in this holiday special. In subsequent specials it is red.

question: In "The 12 Days of Christmas", how many total gifts does her true love give to her?
answerDescription: She gets 1 partridge in a pear tree on each of the 12 days (12); She gets 2 turtle doves on the last 11 days (22); She gets 3 french hens on the last 10 days (30); She gets 4 calling birds on the last 9 days (36); She gets 5 gold rings on the last 8 days (40); She gets 6 geese a-laying on the last 7 days (42); She gets 7 swans a-swimming on the last 6 days (42); She gets 8 maids a-milking on the last 5 days (40); She gets 9 ladies dancing on the last 4 days (36); She gets 10 lords a-leaping on the last 3 days (30); She gets 11 pipers piping on the last 2 days (22); She gets 12 drummers drumming on the last day (12) ... for a total of 364 gifts.

question: Which instrument accompanied the first performance of "Silent Night"?
answerDescription: "Silent Night" was first sung as part of a church service in Austria. A guitar was used for accompaniment because the church organ had been destroyed by mice.

question: Where is Christmas Island located?
answerDescription: Christmas Island is an external territory of the Commonwealth of Australia located in the Indian Ocean. It was discovered on Christmas Day 1643, but only settled in the late 19th century.

question: What Christian group banned Christmas in Boston from 1659 to 1681?
answerDescription: Even though the Puritan ban on Christmas was lifted in 1681, Christmas didn't become popular in Boston until the mid-19th century.

question: What famous Christmas song was written for the musical film Holiday Inn?
answerDescription: Holiday Inn (1942), which stars Bing Crosby and Fred Astaire, features music by Irving Berlin who wrote twelve songs specifically for the film, the best known being "White Christmas".

question: What evil reindeer tries to frame Rudolph in the TV special Rudolph and Frosty's Christmas in July?
answerDescription: Winterbolt, a powerful and wicked snow wizard, recruits a nasty reindeer named Scratcher who takes advantage of Rudolph's kindness and tricks him into stealing money from the circus.

question: Which Christmas song declares "giddy-yap, giddy-yap, giddy-yap it's grand?"
options: HAVE YOURSELF A MERRY LITTLE CHRISTMAS
answerDescription: ASCAP named "Sleigh Ride" the most popular piece of Christmas music in the USA for the four consecutive years 2009 through 2012, based on performance data tracked by airplay monitoring service, Mediaguide.

question: Who was the King of Judea when Jesus was born?
answerDescription: After the birth of Jesus, some magi from the East visited Herod to inquire the whereabouts of "the one having been born king of the Jews", because they had seen his star in the east and wanted to pay him homage. Herod, as King of the Jews, was alarmed at the prospect of a "usurper".

question: Who composed the musical masterpiece "The Messiah"?
answerDescription: Handel's Messiah was composed in 1741 with a scriptural text compiled by Charles Jennens from the King James Bible. After an initially modest public reception, the oratorio has become one of the most frequently performed choral works in Western music.

question: What American author wrote "The Gift of the Magi"?
answerDescription: "The Gift of the Magi" is a short story, written by O. Henry, about a young married couple and how they deal with the challenge of buying secret Christmas gifts for each other with very little money.

question: Where is Christmas Ridge located?
answerDescription: The Christmas Ridge is part of an underwater mountain range in the Pacific Ocean. It was given its name by fishermen because of the great amount of fish that they could catch there. This gave them a lot of money right before Christmas or the year-end holidays.

question: Who said "Maybe Christmas doesn't come from a store, maybe Christmas, perhaps means more"?
answerDescription: Then the Grinch thought of something he hadn't before!"Maybe Christmas," he thought, "doesn't come from a store.""Maybe Christmas ... perhaps ... means a little bit more!"

question: What NBA player went head-to-head against Santa Claus in a Nike commercial?
answerDescription: Even though Michael Jordan embarrasses Santa on the court with some smooth spin moves and a barrage of dunks, the always jolly big man doesn't seem to mind and they leave the court arm in arm.

question: How do churchgoers in the capital city of Venezuela get to Christmas Mass?
answerDescription: The capital city of Venezuela has a neat tradition. The streets in Caracas are closed off in order to allow churchgoers to arrive by roller-skate.

question: In The Polar Express (2004
answerDescription: Billy's Polar Express ticket has the letters B & E punched in it.

question: In the movie Elf (2003
answerDescription: The first rule of The Code Of The Elves is "Treat every day like Christmas."

question: What does the singer of "A Holly Jolly Christmas" have a cup of?
answerDescription: Have a holly jolly ChristmasIt's the best time of the yearI don't know if there'll be snowBut have a cup of cheer

question: "Do You Hear What I Hear?" was originally written in response to _________.
answerDescription: It was written by Noël Regney and Gloria Shayne Baker as a plea for peace during the Cuban Missile Crisis. Regney had been invited by a record producer to write a Christmas song, but was hesitant due to the commercialism of the holiday. It has since sold tens of millions of copies and been covered by hundreds of artists.

question: In the British Christmas carol "I Saw Three Ships", where were the ships sailing?
answerDescription: The lyrics mention the ships sailing into Bethlehem, but the nearest body of water is the Dead Sea about 20 miles (32 km) away.

question: What store sold the first pre-lit Christmas trees?
answerDescription: In the early 1990s the world's largest artificial Christmas tree maker, Boto Company (bankrupted in January 2008) supplied the first pre-lit Christmas trees to Target stores.

question: Why is Kris Kringle arrested in the 1970 TV special Santa Claus Is Comin' to Town?
answerDescription: Kris is arrested by the hateful Burgermeister for smuggling toys into Sombertown.

question: What was Clement C. Moore's Christmas gift to his children in 1822?
options: A MINIATURE SLEIGH AND 8 TINY REINDEER
answerDescription: In 1822, Clement C. Moore's gift to his children was the poem "The Night Before Christmas". This poem has been called "arguably the best-known verses ever written by an American" and is responsible for many of the popular conceptions of Santa Claus from the mid-nineteenth century to today.

question: Where was "Silent Night" first performed?
answerDescription: The song was first performed on Christmas Eve 1818 at St Nicholas parish church in the small town of Oberndorf bei Salzburg, Austria.

question: How do you wish someone a Merry Christmas in Armenian?
answerDescription: At Christmas, Armenians greet each other with the words "Shenorhavor Dzenount".

question: What Christmas plant might be labeled as "Viscum"?
answerDescription: Viscum album is a species of mistletoe in the family Santalaceae, commonly known as European mistletoe, common mistletoe or simply mistletoe. It is associated with Christmas as a decoration, under which lovers are expected to kiss.

question: Who originally sang "Here Comes Santa Claus"?
answerDescription: "Here Comes Santa Claus (Down Santa Claus Lane)" was originally written and performed by Gene Autry, with music composed by Oakley Haldeman. Autry's original version was a top-10 hit on the pop and country charts; the song would go on to be covered many times in the subsequent decades by artists such as Doris Day, Elvis Presley, and Alvin and the Chipmunks.

question: How do you say "Merry Christmas" in Spanish?
answerDescription: "Feliz Navidad" is Merry Christmas in Spanish.

question: In Greece, who is traditionally given the first slice of bread from the Christmas loaf?
answerDescription: Slices of Christopsomo, or "Christ bread", are offered to the first beggar or stranger who comes to the house.

question: What opera debuted in Cairo, Egypt on Christmas Eve 1871?
answerDescription: Set in Egypt, Verdi's Aida was commissioned by and first performed at Cairo's Khedivial Opera House on 24 December 1871.

question: What song was declared an "intangible cultural heritage" by UNESCO in 2011?
answerDescription: "Silent Night" has been recorded by singers from every music genre. The version sung by Bing Crosby is the third best-selling single of all-time.

question: On the tenth day of Christmas, what did my true love give to me?
answerDescription: "On the tenth day of Christmas my true love gave to me ten lords a leaping."

question: What poet wrote "The Cultivation of Christmas Trees"?
answerDescription: What makes Eliot's verses especially memorable is that while they deal with a religious holiday, they speak to a very secular concern: our struggle to hold on to our inborn capacity for wonder, that same essential faculty that fuels both science and spirituality.

question: What political cartoonist is responsible for the modern conception of Santa Claus?
answerDescription: Thomas Nast drew a picture of Santa Claus for the January 1, 1881 issue of Harper's Weekly and the rest of the media ran with it. It became the visual prototype of the Santa Claus we all know and love.

question: What ancient Roman holiday influenced the development of Christmas?
answerDescription: Saturnalia was an ancient Roman festival in honour of the deity Saturn. The holiday was celebrated with a sacrifice at the Temple of Saturn and a public banquet, followed by private gift-giving. As the Roman Empire came under Christian rule, many of its customs were recast into or at least influenced the seasonal celebrations surrounding Christmas.

question: What is the capital of Christmas Island?
answerDescription: About a third of Christmas Island's total population of 1,600 lives in Flying Fish Cove, which lies near the north-eastern tip of the island.

question: Who commissioned the first Christmas cards?
answerDescription: The first Christmas cards were commissioned by Sir Henry Cole and illustrated by John Callcott Horsley in London on 1 May 1843. Two batches totaling 2,050 cards were printed and sold that year for a shilling each.

question: Which country declared Christmas Day a public holiday in 1958?
answerDescription: In Scotland, Christmas Day became a public holiday in 1958. Before that, people worked on Christmas Day, although they still gave presents to their children.

question: In which country is Santa Claus called Babbo Natale?
answerDescription: Babbo Natale, Italy's version of Santa Claus, is becoming more popular and gift giving on Christmas day is becoming more common, but La Befana, the old woman who delivers gifts on Epiphany (January 6) is still the more popular Italian Christmas figure.

question: What did Harry Potter get for his first Christmas at Hogwarts?
answerDescription: Harry also got a lumpy looking jumper from Mrs. Weasley, but the invisibility cloak he received from Dumbledore was much more useful.

question: Which famous scientist was born on Christmas Day?
answerDescription: Sir Isaac Newton was born according to the Julian calendar (in use in England at the time) on Christmas Day, December 25, 1642.

question: According to the 1964 TV special Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer, who is Rudolph's father?
answerDescription: Rudolph's father, Santa's lead reindeer Donner, feels ashamed after Santa Claus tells him that he won't allow Rudolph to be in the sleigh team with his nose ("Jingle Jingle Jingle"). Donner uses a special cover to hide Rudolph's nose so he can send Rudolph to the Reindeer Games.

question: What year was Christmas first celebrated on December 25th?
answerDescription: The first recorded date of Christmas being celebrated on December 25th was in 336, during the time of the Roman Emperor Constantine (he was the first Christian Roman Emperor). A few years later, Pope Julius I officially declared that the birth of Jesus would be celebrated on the 25th of December.

question: Who is George Bailey's guardian angel in It's a Wonderful Life?
answerDescription: George Bailey's imminent suicide on Christmas Eve brings about the intervention of his guardian angel, Clarence Odbody. Clarence shows George all the lives he has touched and how different life in his community of Bedford Falls would be had he never been born.

question: Which famous singer died on Christmas Day?
answerDescription: In 1995, Rat Pack member Dean Martin died on Christmas Day, at the age of 78. The Godfather of Soul, James Brown, died on Christmas Day, 2006. He was 73 years old and had been hospitalized for pneumonia. Actress, singer and comedian Eartha Kitt died of colon cancer on Christmas Day in 2008.

question: Which historic event happened on Christmas Day?
options: NORWAY'S FIRST EVER SHIPMENT OF BANANAS
NEIL ARMSTRONG WALKED ON THE MOON
answerDescription: In one of the most famous and decisive moments of the American Revolution, General George Washington led his army across the Delaware River to Trenton, New Jersey, with the password "Victory or Death." In the evening of December 25, 1776, they captured 1,000 Hessian soldiers in a surprise attack that raised morale in Washington's troops and turned the tide of the war.

question: Where did Mary and Joseph go after leaving Bethlehem?
answerDescription: The flight into Egypt is a biblical event described in the Gospel of Matthew (Matthew 2:13-23). Soon after the visit by the Magi, who had learned that King Herod intended to kill the infants of that area, an angel appeared to Joseph in a dream to tell him to flee to Egypt with Mary and his infant son Jesus.

question: In Spain, it is a tradition to eat what at the stroke of midnight on New Year's Eve?
answerDescription: It is rare to find a Spaniard who will risk poisoning their fate for the coming year by skipping the New Year's Eve grapes, one for each stroke of midnight.

question: What ornament is traditionally placed on top of a Christmas tree?
answerDescription: Angels usually appear on top of Christmas trees, representing their role in the holiday celebrating the birth of Jesus.

question: Who was the star of the Christmas movie Jingle All the Way?
answerDescription: The plot of Jingle All the Way focuses on two rival fathers, workaholic Howard Langston (Arnold Schwarzenegger) and stressed out postal worker Myron Larabee (Sinbad), both desperately trying to get a Turbo-Man action figure for their respective sons on a last minute shopping spree on Christmas Eve.

question: In "The Twelve Days of Christmas", how many french hens are there?
answerDescription: On the third day of Christmas my true love sent to meThree french hens

question: In Charles Dickens' A Christmas Carol, who did Ebeneezer Scrooge serve his apprenticeship under?
answerDescription: Scrooge is the very antithesis of the person he worked for as a young man. Mr. Fezziwig is portrayed as a jovial, foppish man with a large Welsh wig.

question: What was the last U.S. state to recognize Christmas as an official holiday?
answerDescription: Alabama was the first state in the U.S. to officially recognize Christmas in 1836. Oklahoma was the last state to declare Christmas a legal holiday in 1907.

question: Easter celebrates the ________ of Jesus Christ.
answerDescription: Easter celebrates the resurrection of Jesus from the dead.

question: What color were the first Easter eggs?
answerDescription: The Christian custom of Easter eggs started among the early Christians of Mesopotamia, who stained eggs with red colouring in memory of the blood of Christ, shed at His crucifixion.

question: How many days after his burial did Jesus rise from the dead?
answerDescription: On the third day, he rose again.

question: When is Easter celebrated?
options: 1ST SUNDAY AFTER THE SUN CROSSES THE CELESTIAL EQUATOR
1ST SUNDAY AFTER 1ST FULL MOON AFTER SPRING EQUINOX
answerDescription: In 325CE the Council of Nicaea established that Easter would be held on the first Sunday after the first full moon occurring on or after the vernal equinox.

question: What plant has come to symbolize Jesus' resurrection?
answerDescription: In many Christian churches, the chancel is adorned with Easter lilies throughout the Easter season. According to pious legend, after Jesus' death and resurrection, some of these beautiful flowers were found growing in the Garden of Gethsemane, where he had gone the night before His crucifixion. Legend has it that these flowers sprang up where drops of Jesus' sweat fell as he prayed.

question: The Easter Bunny originated in what country?
answerDescription: Originating among German Lutherans, the "Easter Hare" originally played the role of a judge, evaluating whether children were good or disobedient in behavior at the start of the season of Eastertide.

question: Which apostle doubted Jesus' resurrection?
answerDescription: A doubting Thomas is a skeptic who refuses to believe without direct personal experience--a reference to the Apostle Thomas, who refused to believe that the resurrected Jesus had appeared to the ten other apostles, until he could see and feel the wounds received by Jesus on the cross.

question: In whose tomb was Jesus buried?
answerDescription: Joseph of Arimathea wrapped him in cloth and prepared Him for burial.

question: What is an Australian alternative to the Easter Bunny?
answerDescription: Bilbies are native Australian marsupials that are endangered. To raise money and increase awareness of conservation efforts, bilby-shaped chocolates and related merchandise are sold within many stores throughout Australia as an alternative to Easter bunnies.

question: According to the gospel of Mark, who did Jesus first appear to after his resurrection?
answerDescription: MARK 16:9-11: "Now when He rose early on the first day of the week, He appeared first to Mary Magdalene, out of whom He had cast seven demons. She went and told those who had been with Him, as they mourned and wept. And when they heard that He was alive and had been seen by her, they did not believe.

question: What immediately precedes Easter?
answerDescription: Lent begins on Ash Wednesday and ends approximately six weeks later, before Easter Sunday.

question: In It's the Easter Beagle, Charlie Brown, Snoopy delivers Easter eggs to everyone except _______.
answerDescription: Snoopy runs out of eggs by the time he gets to Charlie Brown and gives his friend the now empty basket.

question: 76% of people eat which part of an Easter bunny first?
answerDescription: According to a recent survey, most people start with the ears.

question: What was written above Jesus' head on the cross?
answerDescription: Matthew 27:37 tells us "Above his head they placed the written charge against him: THIS IS JESUS: KING OF THE JEWS".

question: What kind of cloth was used to wrap the body of Jesus?
answerDescription: The Gospels of Matthew, Mark, and Luke state that Joseph of Arimathea wrapped the body of Jesus with spices in linen cloths, according to the burial custom of the Jews.

question: How much do Americans spend on Easter candy each year?
answerDescription: Americans spend $1.9 billion on Easter candy, making it the second biggest candy holiday after Halloween.

question: What pastry marks the end of Lent in many countries including the British Isles, Australia, and New Zealand?
answerDescription: A hot cross bun is a spiced sweet bun made with currants or raisins, marked with a cross on the top, and traditionally eaten on Good Friday.

question: What pagan goddess is sometimes associated with Easter?
answerDescription: Anglo-Saxons once held feasts in honor of Ostara (or Eostre), the goddess of fertility, but this tradition eventually died out and was replaced by the Christian celebration of the resurrection of Jesus.

question: Which U.S. President held the first Easter Egg Roll?
answerDescription: The first annual White House Easter Egg Roll was held on April 22, 1878, after President Rutherford B. Hayes agreed to open the White House grounds on Easter Monday to children who wanted to roll Easter eggs.

question: How long does it take to make a Marshmallow Peep?
answerDescription: In 1953, it took 27 hours to make one Marshmallow Peep. Today, it takes six minutes.

question: What is the Friday before Easter usually called?
answerDescription: Good Friday commemorates the crucifixion of Jesus Christ and his death at Calvary. It is observed during Holy Week and may coincide with the Jewish observance of Passover.

question: Pysanka is a traditional way of painting Easter Eggs. In which country does this method originate?
answerDescription: A pysanka is a Ukrainian Easter egg, decorated with traditional folk designs using a wax-resist method. The word pysanka comes from the verb pysaty, "to write", as the designs are not painted on, but written with beeswax.

question: Who did Pilate release instead of Jesus?
answerDescription: There was a prevailing Passover custom in Jerusalem that allowed Pilate, the praefectus or governor of Judea, to commute one prisoner's death sentence by popular acclaim. According to accounts in all four gospels, the crowd chose Barabbas to be released and Jesus of Nazareth to be crucified.

question: At the Last Supper, what food did Jesus compare his body to?
answerDescription: Bread and wine were present at the Last Supper. Jesus is said to have passed both around the table, telling his Apostles that the bread was his body and the wine was his blood. This is the scriptural origin of communion.

question: What was the purpose of the Easter Act of 1928?
options: TO ABOLISH THE PAGAN FESTIVAL ASSOCIATED WITH EASTER
TO PREVENT THE COMMERCIALIZATION OF EASTER
TO SET A FIXED DATE FOR EASTER
answerDescription: The purpose of the Act was to set a fixed date for Easter, but it has never been enforced.

question: In It's the Easter Beagle, Charlie Brown, who is the only member of the Peanuts Gang who believes Linus when he tells them that the Easter Beagle will take care of everything?
answerDescription: Only Sally believes him, though she still has some doubts after their Halloween failure to find The Great Pumpkin.

question: Which of the following is a traditional Easter bread in Russia?
answerDescription: Traditionally after the Easter service, the kulich, which has been put into a basket and decorated with colorful flowers, is blessed by the priest. Blessed kulich is eaten before breakfast each day.

question: Who wrote the traditional Easter hymn "Up from the Grave He Arose"?
answerDescription: Robert Lowry (1826-1899) was an American professor of literature, a Baptist minister and composer of gospel hymns.

question: What kind of crown did the Romans give Jesus?
answerDescription: According to three of the synoptic Gospels, a crown of thorns was placed on Jesus' head during the events leading up to the crucifixion. It was one of the instruments of the Passion, employed by Jesus' captors both to cause him pain and to mock his claim of authority.

question: How much did the world's largest Easter egg weigh?
answerDescription: It was measured at Le Acciaierie Shopping Centre, in Cortenuova, Italy on April 16, 2011. The chocolate Easter egg weighed 15,873 lbs and had a circumference of 64 ft, 3.65 in.

question: When did the New York City Easter Parade first become a tradition?
answerDescription: Starting as a spontaneous event in the 1870s, the New York Easter parade became increasingly popular in the mid-20th century--in 1947, it was estimated to draw over a million people.

question: In what country do kids dress as Easter Wizards instead of Easter Bunnies?
answerDescription: In Sweden, kids dress up as wizards and witches rather than bunnies. Apparently, this was all a big mix-up, as German immigrants brought the idea of the Easter Bunny with them to Sweden, only to find that the Swedish word for the Easter Bunny, "Påskharen", sounds very similar to "Påskkarlen," which means the Easter Wizard. And since the good people of Sweden have always held at least a little bit to their old pagan ways, they were totally cool with adopting Gandalf as the symbol of Easter.

question: Which country boasts the largest Easter egg collection?
answerDescription: Over 1500 Easter eggs from all over the world are gathered in the Easter Egg Museum in Ciechanowiec, Poland, founded by Irena Stasiewicz-Jasiukowa and Jerzy Jasiuk.

question: Which traditional Easter hymn includes the lyrics: "Oh, precious is the flow that makes me white as snow"?
answerDescription: Oh, precious is the flowThat makes me white as snowNo other fount I knowNothing but the blood of Jesus

question: Which book of the Bible mentions an Easter hare?
answerDescription: Despite being widely associated with the Christian holiday, the Easter bunny is never mentioned in the Bible.

question: What were the original Marshmallow Peeps?
answerDescription: The yellow chicks were the original form of the candy (hence their name) but the manufacturer would go on to introduce other colors and, eventually, the myriad shapes in which they are now produced.

question: What percent of Americans go to church on Easter Sunday?
answerDescription: According to a recent survey by the National Retail Federation, about 50% of all Americans plan to attend church on Easter Sunday.

question: Which composer introduced the idea of the Easter bonnet into American popular culture?
answerDescription: In 1933, Irving Berlin introduced the Easter Bonnet into American pop culture with his ballad "Easter Parade", in which he wrote:"In your Easter bonnet with all the frills upon it,You'll be the grandest lady in the Easter parade"

question: Which bread product is associated with Easter?
answerDescription: According to some sources, the twists of the pretzel are meant to look like arms crossed in prayer.

question: The original Marshmallow Peeps had _____.
answerDescription: Their wings were clipped in 1955, two years after the first marshmallow chicks hatched, to give the candy a sleeker, more "modern" look.

question: What are the eyes of Marshmallow Peeps made of?
answerDescription: The eyes are made of carnauba, a non-toxic edible wax, which is also found in shoe polish.

question: What animal brings Easter eggs in Switzerland?
answerDescription: Swiss children fill their baskets on Easter morning by hunting for colored eggs left by the Easter Cuckoo.

question: Who plays the Easter Bunny in the 2012 film Rise of the Guardians?
answerDescription: Hugh Jackman plays E. Aster Bunnymund (the Easter Bunny), the fabled keeper and bringer of Easter eggs and the Guardian of Hope.

question: The first Jack-o-Lanterns were made out of what?
answerDescription: The first Jack-o-Lanterns were made in Ireland out of hollowed-out turnips. A piece of coal was inserted into the hollow and the "lantern" was meant to guide the way of poor old Jack who wasn't welcome in Heaven but was also barred from entering Hell for tricking the devil. According to legend, the devil gave this crude lamp to Jack so that he could walk the earth forever in limbo. When the Irish brought this tradition to America, they apparently decided that pumpkins were easier to carve than turnips, and the modern-day Jack-o-Lantern was born!

question: Halloween is generally considered to have evolved from what ancient festival?
answerDescription: Although there are many theories on the origin and history of Halloween, it is generally accepted that Halloween dates back to an ancient Celtic festival known as Samhain, or the Celtic New Year. It was believed that the spirits of everyone who had died during the year would return on the eve of Samhain to seek living bodies to possess for the following year. The Celts would dress in ghoulish costumes and hold noisy revels in an attempt to frighten away the restless dead, and there are many accounts of people being burned at the stake because they were perceived to have been possessed by one of the returning spirits.

question: According to legend, a unibrow, tattoos, and a long middle finger are all signs of what Halloween creature?
answerDescription: According to legend, a unibrow, tattoos, hairy palms, and a long middle finger are all signs of a werewolf. Other common traits include unusual strength, an irrational fear of water, and glow-in-the-dark red eyes!

question: In what century did the practice of trick-or-treating begin?
answerDescription: In North America, trick-or-treating began to develop as a Halloween tradition during the 1920s, but the European tradition of going house-to-house collecting food at Halloween goes back at least as far as the 16th century. In Britain and Ireland, there are many accounts of people going house-to-house in costume at Halloween, reciting verses in exchange for food, and sometimes warning of misfortune if they were not welcomed.

question: Which of the following is NOT a term for a scarecrow?
answerDescription: There are a wide range of alternative names for scarecrows including Hodmedod, Murmet, Hay-man, Gallybagger, Tattie Bogal, Mommet, Mawkin, and Bwbach. Doodle sack is an old English word for bagpipe.

question: From base to point, what is the order of colors on a piece of candy corn?
answerDescription: Yellow, orange white is the progression of standard candy corn. The "indian corn" variation is brown at the widest end.

question: Which of these Halloween films was NOT directed by Tim Burton?
answerDescription: The Nightmare Before Christmas was produced and conceived by Tim Burton, but it was directed by Henry Selick.

question: What might you "bob" for on Halloween?
answerDescription: Bobbing for apples is a traditional Halloween game in which a tub or large basin is filled with apples and water. Because apples are less dense than water, they will float at the surface. Players then try to catch one with their teeth.

question: If you want to keep spirits out of your home on Halloween, what should you sprinkle on your doorstep?
answerDescription: According to tradition, salt can be laid around the boundaries of a room to prevent spirits and demons from entering.

question: What classic horror film is based on a true story?
answerDescription: The Amityville Horror is based on the alleged experiences of the Lutz family who bought a new home on 112 Ocean Avenue in Amityville, New York, a house where a mass murder had been committed the year before.

question: According to superstition, if you stare into a mirror at midnight on Halloween, what will you see?
answerDescription: According to superstition, if you stare into a mirror at midnight on Halloween, you will see your future spouse.

question: In It's the Great Pumpkin, Charlie Brown, who does Linus mistake for the Great Pumpkin?
answerDescription: When Linus sees a shadowy figure rising from the moonlit patch, he assumes the Great Pumpkin has arrived, and faints. When Sally sees that it is only Snoopy, she yells at Linus for making her miss out on the Halloween festivities.

question: What Michael Jackson song was adapted by American Werewolf In London director John Landis into a highly successful Halloween-themed music video?
answerDescription: "Thriller" was adapted by John Landis into a highly successful music video. In the video's most iconic scene, Jackson leads other actors costumed as zombies in a choreographed dance routine.

question: What product is banned in Hollywood on Halloween?
answerDescription: Silly string fans should stay far away from Hollywood on Halloween. An ordinance banning the toy, first introduced in 2004 after complaints from Hollywood Boulevard property owners, is only enforced on October 31. If you're caught with sticky hands, expect to pay a $1,000 fine.

question: How many colors of M&Ms are there in a normal bag?
answerDescription: There are six colors in a normal bag: red, orange, yellow, green, blue, and brown.

question: What ghost did British Prime Minister Winston Churchill reportedly see in the White House?
answerDescription: A well-known ghost story was reported by Churchill, who was a guest at the White House. After a long bath, and naked except for a cigar, he walked into the adjoining bedroom -- and there was Abraham Lincoln at the fireplace. Churchill said, "Good evening, Mr. President. You seem to have me at a disadvantage." He reported that Lincoln smiled softly and then disappeared.

question: In the popular Halloween Candy Buyback program, kids sell their uneaten candy to local dentists who redistribute it to whom?
answerDescription: The Candy Buyback program not only encourages kids to eat less candy on Halloween, but it's a great way to support the troops.

question: How is the "mystery flavor" of Dum Dums lollipops made?
options: IT'S JUST A REGULAR DUM DUM WITH A DIFFERENT WRAPPER
IT'S EITHER PINEAPPLE OR BUTTERED POPCORN
IT'S AN OVERLAP OF TWO BATCHES OF CANDY
IT'S A RANDOM MIX OF LEFTOVER INGREDIENTS
answerDescription: Rather than shut down production and clean out the machine between batches, the company keeps the lollipops that combine a little of Flavor A and a little of Flavor B, giving them a wrapper covered in question marks and marketing them as Mystery Flavor.

question: What horror film is widely regarded to have popularized the found footage film technique?
answerDescription: The Blair Witch Project, which tells the fictional story of three student filmmakers lost in the Black Hills, was later employed by similarly successful films such as Paranormal Activity and Cloverfield.

question: What does it mean if you see a blue pumpkin while trick-or-treating?
answerDescription: If you see a blue pumpkin, that means the house is handing out allergy-free treats. Of course, it could also mean the house is using last year's pumpkin.

question: What was the name of Gomez and Morticia's daughter on The Addams Family?
answerDescription: Wednesday was the youngest member of the Addams family, a strange yet sweet-natured little girl who pursued such hobbies as raising spiders and beheading dolls (called "Marie Antoinette," "Mary Queen of Scots," and "Little Red Riding Hood").

question: What Halloween costume does E.T. wear?
answerDescription: On Halloween, Michael and Elliott dress E.T. as a ghost so they can sneak him out of the house.

question: What Halloween radio drama caused a mass panic on October 30, 1938?
options: THE FALL OF THE HOUSE OF USHER
answerDescription: The War of the Worlds was a Halloweed episode of The Mercury Theatre on the Air. Directed and narrated by Orson Welles, the episode (adapted from H. G. Wells' famous novel about an alien invasion and broadcast as if it were a real news program) became famous for allegedly causing mass hysteria, although the scale of the panic is disputed as the program had relatively few listeners.

question: What was the most popular Halloween candy in 2004?
answerDescription: According to the Extreme Chocolate annual Halloween candy survey, Candy Corn was the most popular Halloween candy in 2004. In previous years, Snickers had held the #1 spot.

question: What was the most popular Halloween costume in 2004?
answerDescription: According to the National Retail Federation's Halloween Consumer Intentions and Actions Survey, the most popular Halloween costume in 2004 was Spiderman, with 2.15 million children dressing as their favorite superhero. Other popular costumes included princesses (1.8 million children), witches (1.3 million) and vampires (899,000).

question: How much does the world's biggest pumpkin weigh?
answerDescription: The world record for heaviest pumpkin is currently held by a gigantic gourd weighing a whopping 2,096 pounds--as much as a small car! Beni Meier, the Swiss gardener who grew the massive fruit, had to use a special vehicle to transport it. The world record was previously held by California couple Tim and Susan Mathison.

question: How many pounds of candy did the average American consume in 2002?
answerDescription: The average American consumed 24 pounds of candy in 2002! It is believed that the largest portion is consumed by kids on and during the days immediately following Halloween.

question: How many "witches" were burned at the stake in the Salem Witch Trials?
answerDescription: None of the "witches" put to death in the Salem Witch trials were burned at the stake. All those executed were hanged but one, Giles Cory, who was pressed to death. Several others died in prison, including Sarah Osborne, Roger Toothaker, Lyndia Dustin, and Ann Foster.

question: What phobia do you suffer from if you have an intense fear of Halloween?
answerDescription: Samhainophobia refers to an abnormal and persistent fear of Halloween. This time of year may also stir up other phobias such as the fear of: cats (ailurophobia), witches (wiccaphobia), ghosts (phasmophobia), spiders (arachnophobia), the dark (nyctophobia), and cemetaries (coimetrophobia).

question: What was the first individually wrapped penny candy in America?
answerDescription: Tootsie Rolls, invented by Leo Hirschfield in 1907, were the first penny candy to be individually wrapped in America.

question: Where did the inventor of the Ouija board get the name "Ouija"?
options: FROM THE EGYPTIAN BOOK OF THE DEAD
answerDescription: According to Charles Kennard, one of the original manufacturers of the Ouija board, William Fuld (who is credited with naming the device) learned the name "Ouija" from using the board. Years later, Fuld would change his story, claiming it was merely a combination of the French and German words for "yes".

question: What does the word "Halloween" mean?
answerDescription: It means "hallowed evening" or "holy night".

question: What Christian holiday does Halloween immediately precede?
answerDescription: All Saints' Day, also known as All Hallows, Day of All the Saints, Solemnity of All Saints, or Feast of All Saints is a festival celebrated on November 1st by the Latin Church of the Roman Catholic Church and some other Western Christian traditions, and on the first Sunday after Pentecost in Eastern Catholicism and Eastern Orthodoxy, in honour of all the saints, known and unknown.

question: When did the word "vampire" first appear in English?
answerDescription: The Oxford English Dictionary dates the first appearance of the English word vampire (as vampyre) from 1734, in a travelogue titled Travels of Three English Gentlemen.

question: What is trick-or-treating called in Mexico?
answerDescription: In Mexico, the practice of trick-or-treating is called calaverita (Spanish for "little skull"). Instead of saying "trick or treat", the children ask ¿me da mi calaverita? ("can you give me my little skull?"). A calaverita is a small skull made of sugar or chocolate.

question: What colors are associated with Halloween?
answerDescription: Black and orange are typically associated with Halloween. Orange is a symbol of harvest and autumn. Black is a symbol of death and darkness and acts as a reminder that Halloween once was a festival that marked the boundaries between life and death.

question: Which practice may have evolved into trick-or-treating?
answerDescription: The modern practice of trick-or-treating may have evolved from several customs such as mumming (going door-to-door performing scenes for food), souling (begging "soul-cakes" by singing under windows), and guising (wearing costumes at Hallowmas).

question: During Samhain, what did the Druids do with cats?
answerDescription: During the ancient celebration of Samhain, Druids were said to throw cats into a fire, often in wicker cages, as part of divination proceedings.

question: In Ewe folklore, what form can a vampire take?
answerDescription: The adze is a vampiric being in Ewe folklore that can take the form of a firefly, though it will transform into human shape upon capture.

question: In It's the Great Pumpkin, Charlie Brown, which trick-or-treating character gets nothing but rocks?
answerDescription: During trick-or-treating, the kids receive various goodies -- except for Charlie Brown, who gets nothing but rocks.

question: Who died on Halloween night?
answerDescription: Harry Houdini was one of the most famous and mysterious magicians who ever lived. Strangely enough, he died in 1926 on Halloween night.

question: According to tradition, what will you see if you wear your clothes inside out and then walks backwards on Halloween?
answerDescription: According to an old Halloween tradition, you will see a witch at midnight if you wear your clothes inside out and walk backwards.

question: In The Nightmare Before Christmas, what character discovers a portal from "Halloween Town" to "Christmas Town"?
answerDescription: Jack Skellington leads the citizens of Halloween Town in organizing the annual Halloween holiday, but he's grown weary of the same routine year after year, and when he discovers a portal to Christmas Town, he decides to celebrate that holiday instead.

question: In what country did girls believe they could see images of their future husband if they hung wet sheets in front of the fire on Halloween?
answerDescription: In Scotland, young girls often hung wet sheets in front of a fire on Halloween, hoping to see images of their future husbands.

question: In what Halloween classic does Max Dennison accidentally resurrect three witches from the Salem witch trials?
answerDescription: In Hocus Pocus, Max lights the Black Flame Candle and inadvertently resurrects the Sanderson sisters, three witches who plot to suck out the souls of all Salem's children, beginning with Max's sister Dani!

question: What was the first city in the U.S. to plan an official Halloween celebration?
answerDescription: Anoka, Minnesota is believed to be the first city in the United States to put on a Halloween celebration to divert its youngsters from Halloween pranks. When Anokans awoke to find their cows roaming Main Street, their windows soaped and their outhouses tipped over, they decided something had to be done. In 1920, a Halloween parade was scheduled, and afterward, hundreds of bags of popcorn, candy, peanuts and other treats were given away to the children who marched in the parade. By the 1930s, it was estimated that 20,000 spectators lined the streets to watch this annual event.

question: According to Google Frightgeist, what was the most popular Halloween costume of 2015?
answerDescription: According to Google Frightgeist, Harley Quinn was the most searched costume of 2015.

question: What actress made her film debut in the original Halloween movie?
answerDescription: Jamie Lee Curtis made her film debut in the 1978 slasher film Halloween.

question: What percent of adults celebrate Halloween?
answerDescription: According to a National Retail Federation poll 68.5% of adults celebrate Halloween.

question: What candy was originally called "chicken feed"?
answerDescription: The Goelitz Confectionery Company began production of candy corn at the turn of the century and called the product "Chicken Feed".

question: What monster is pictured on the flag of Sicily?
answerDescription: The flag of Sicily depicts the head of Medusa (a gorgon with a head of snakes), surrounded by three bent running legs, and three stalks of wheat.

question: What Halloween song by Bobby "Boris" Pickett topped the Billboard charts in 1962?
answerDescription: "Monster Mash" was #1 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart in October 1962 and has been a perennial holiday favorite ever since.

question: What kind of candy wants you to "Taste the Rainbow"?
answerDescription: Skittles "Taste the rainbow" campaign is one of the longest running advertising campaigns in history.

question: Which ailment did people believe could be cured by pumpkins?
answerDescription: Years ago, people believed that pumpkins could cure freckles and snakebites.

question: What society did Dr. Donald A. Reed found in 1962?
answerDescription: He founded the Count Dracula Society. To this day, there are vampire clubs and societies with people claiming to be real vampires.

question: Who wrote The Legend of Sleepy Hollow?
answerDescription: Written while Washington Irving was living abroad in Birmingham, England, "The Legend of Sleepy Hollow" was first published in 1820.

question: What monster is said to prey on children and women in labor?
answerDescription: The Penanggalan is a ghost of Southeast Asian folk mythology. A variation of the vampire myth, the Penanggalan is said to be a detached female head capable of flying about on its own.

question: What was Anne Rice's debut novel?
answerDescription: Published in 1976, Interview with the Vampire was based on a short story Rice wrote around 1968. The novel centers on vampire Louis de Pointe du Lac, who tells the story of his life to a reporter.

question: What supernatural creature in Latin American folklore is said to drink the blood of chickens and goats?
answerDescription: The chupacabra is a legendary creature in the folklore of parts of the Americas, with its first purported sightings reported in Puerto Rico. The name comes from the animal's reported habit of attacking and drinking the blood of livestock, especially goats.

question: What monster is said to terrorize the people of Africa?
answerDescription: What the Abominable Snowman is to Asia, or Bigfoot is to America, the Nandi Bear is to Africa. It is one of the most notorious of those legendary beasts which have, so far, eluded capture and the collector's rifle.

question: How long did it take to shoot the movie Halloween?
answerDescription: Halloween was shot in only 21 days in 1978 on a very limited budget. The movie was shot in the Spring and used fake autumn leaves.

question: Novelist Emily Grand Hutchings claimed that she wrote her novel Jap Herron by channeling what famous writer through a Ouija board?
answerDescription: In 1917, novelist Emily Grand Hutchings claimed that her book Jap Herron was dictated by Mark Twain himself, from whom she started receiving messages 2 years prior to the release of the book. 13 years before she started writing the book with the help of a Ouija board, Hutchings corresponded with Twain via letters, mostly asking his advice on writing.

question: What M&M color was added in 1995?
answerDescription: In 1995, the Mars candy company decided that having two shades of brown M&Ms were unnecessary, so they did away with the light brown ones, leaving only the colors red, yellow, green, dark brown, and orange. Mars held a replacement contest, inviting candy lovers to call a 1-800 number and vote for their favorite color: blue, pink, or purple. Blue won, and M&M's haven't looked the same since.

question: Transylvania is a region in which country?
answerDescription: Transylvania is a historical region located in what is today the central part of Romania. In the English-speaking world it is commonly associated with vampires, due to the influence of Bram Stoker's novel Dracula.

question: According to superstition, a person born on Halloween has what special ability?
answerDescription: A person born on Halloween can see and talk to spirits.

question: Who is said to haunt the White House Rose Garden?
answerDescription: First Lady Dolley Madison planted the famous White House rose garden in the early 1800s, and then 100 years later, First Lady Ellen Wilson requested the garden be dug up. But garden workers reported that Dolley Madison's ghost appeared and refused to let them tear up her garden. Since then, an unexplained smell of roses is sometimes experienced inside the White House.

question: What was used to simulate blood in Night of the Living Dead?
answerDescription: When the zombies are eating the bodies in the burnt-out truck they were actually eating roast ham covered in chocolate sauce. The filmmakers joked that it was so nausea inducing that it was almost a waste of time putting the makeup on the zombies, as they ended up looking pale and sick anyway.

question: According to superstition, how do you get rid of a ghost?
options: SHOOT IT WITH A SILVER BULLET
answerDescription: If you see a ghost, walk around it nine times, and it will disappear.

question: What kind of chainsaw was used in The Texas Chain Saw Massacre?
answerDescription: The chainsaw used in this film was a Poulan 245A, with a piece of black tape covering the Poulan logo in order to avoid a possible lawsuit.

question: How many Oscars was the movie Psycho nominated for?
answerDescription: Psycho was nominated for four Oscars, including Best Director, Best Cinematography, Best Art Direction, and Best Actress in a Supporting Role.

question: According to superstition, what happens if you point at a grave?
answerDescription: Don't point at a grave or your finger will rot off.

question: How many pounds did Boris Karloff lose during the filming of Bride of Frankenstein?
answerDescription: Karloff sweated off 20 pounds laboring in the hot costume and makeup.

question: In Joss Whedon's Buffy the Vampire Slayer, who is Buffy's Watcher?
answerDescription: Giles researches the supernatural creatures that Buffy must face, offers insights into their origins and advice on how to defeat them.

question: Who wrote the score for the movie Halloween?
answerDescription: One major reason for the success of Halloween (1978) is the moody musical score, particularly the main theme, which consists of a piano melody played in a 10/8 or "complex 5/4" meter composed and performed by director John Carpenter. It took Carpenter three days to compose the entire score for the film.

question: In Bram Stoker's Dracula, which character is an inmate at the lunatic asylum overseen by Dr. John Seward?
answerDescription: R. M. Renfield suffers from delusions which compel him to eat living creatures in the hope of obtaining their life-force for himself.

question: What is Dr. Frankenstein's first name?
answerDescription: Victor Frankenstein is the title character of Mary Shelley's 1818 novel Frankenstein; or, The Modern Prometheus. He is a scientist who, after studying chemical processes and the decay of living beings, gains an insight into the creation of life and gives life to his own creature, often referred to as Frankenstein's monster, or simply "Frankenstein".

question: What is Casper the Friendly Ghost's last name?
answerDescription: According to the 1995 feature film Casper, his family name is McFadden, making his "full" name Casper McFadden.

question: What was the world's first combination candy bar?
answerDescription: In 1912, in a copper kettle at the Standard Candy Company at Clark & First Avenue in Nashville, TN, the world's first ever combination candy bar was invented--a roundish mound of caramel, marshmallow nougat, fresh roasted peanuts and real milk chocolate known as the Goo Goo Cluster.

question: What animated short features Mickey Mouse, Donald Duck and Goofy hunting ghosts?
answerDescription: Lonesome Ghosts is a Disney animated cartoon, released three days after Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1937). The short features Mickey Mouse, Donald Duck and Goofy as members of The Ajax Ghost Exterminators.

question: What Halloween staple did George Renninger invent?
answerDescription: George Renninger, a candy maker at the Wunderle Candy Company of Philadelphia in the 1880s, invented Candy Corn which he originally called "chicken feed" because corn was commonly used to feed livestock. After World War II, advertisers began marketing it as a special Halloween treat due to its colors that match those of the fall harvest.

question: In The Nightmare Before Christmas, what was Oogie Boogie made of?
answerDescription: Oogie Boogie was the main antagonist of Tim Burton's The Nightmare Before Christmas. He was a burlap sack filled with insects, spiders and a snake for a tongue.

question: Who played the title role in the 1941 film The Wolf Man?
answerDescription: Lon Chaney, Jr. would reprise his classic role as "The Wolf Man" in four sequels, beginning with Frankenstein Meets the Wolf Man in 1943.

question: In the classic movie, The Thing, what exactly is "The Thing"?
answerDescription: The film's title refers to its primary antagonist: a parasitic extraterrestrial lifeform that assimilates other organisms.

question: What is the name of the killer in the Halloween movies?
answerDescription: Michael Myers is the primary antagonist in the Halloween films, except Halloween III: Season of the Witch, which is not connected in continuity to the rest of the films.

question: What was the first film "Master of Horror" Wes Craven directed?
options: THE LAST HOUSE ON THE LEFT
answerDescription: Craven's first feature film as director was The Last House on the Left, which was released in 1972.

question: Who are the three witches in the movie Hocus Pocus?
answerDescription: The Sanderson sisters (Winifred, Sarah and Mary) are played by Bette Midler, Kathy Najimy & Sarah Jessica Parker.

question: What country did Halloween originate in?
answerDescription: Halloween has its origins in Samhain, a Gaelic festival celebrated in Ireland, Scotland and the Isle of Man. Samhain marked the end of the harvest season and the beginning of winter or the "darker half" of the year.

question: Which classic horror film was NOT made by Alfred Hitchcock?
answerDescription: The Shining (1980) was produced and directed by Stanley Kubrick.

question: How is the character Michael Myers credited in the first two Halloween films?
answerDescription: Michael Myers made his first appearance in the original 1978 film, Halloween, although the masked character is credited as "The Shape" in the first two films.

question: What was the Halloween-themed prequel to How the Grinch Stole Christmas?
answerDescription: Most people probably don't realize that there's actually a prequel to the famous How the Grinch Stole Christmas, and it's a Halloween story. Halloween Is Grinch Night premiered on ABC on October 29, 1977 and even won an Emmy Award for Outstanding Animated Program.

question: What was the longest-running supernatural-themed sitcom of the 1960s-1970s?
answerDescription: Bewitched starred Elizabeth Montgomery as a witch who marries an ordinary mortal man, and vows to lead the life of a typical suburban housewife.

question: In what horror film does news anchor Karen White transform into a werewolf during a live broadcast?
answerDescription: In The Howling, Karen resolves to warn the world about the existence of werewolves, and surprises her employers by launching into her warning during a live television news broadcast. Then, to prove her story, she herself transforms into a werewolf.

question: What late-night host joked about electrocuting trick-or-treaters?
answerDescription: On November 1, 2013, David Letterman joked: "Did everybody have a good Halloween? I'm just not into the Halloween spirit. What I did was I went to bed early after I turned on the electric fence."

question: What Halloween comedy stars Bill Murray, Dan Aykroyd and Harold Ramis?
answerDescription: Ghostbusters features Murray, Aykroyd and Ramis as eccentric parapsychologists who start a ghost-catching business in New York City.

question: What are the names of the Addams Family's pet piranhas?
answerDescription: Tristan and Isolde live in an aquarium in the Addams family mansion and eat very quickly.

question: What is the name of Wednesday's pet spider on The Addams Family?
answerDescription: Wednesday's favorite pet is a black widow spider named Homer, although she also has a lizard named Lucifer.
