It tells the story of a gay couple, Georges, the manager of a Saint-Tropez nightclub featuring drag entertainment, and Albin, his romantic partner and star attraction, and the farcical adventures that ensue when Georges's son, Jean-Michel, brings home his fiancée's ultra-conservative parents to meet them. The show's Act One finale, "I Am What I Am", received praise as a "gay anthem," and has been widely recorded.

question: Why does Tevye disown Chava in Fiddler on the Roof?
options: SHE MARRIES OUTSIDE THE JEWISH FAITH
SHE BETRAYS HIM TO THE RUSSIANS
SHE BECOMES PREGNANT OUT OF WEDLOCK
answerDescription: Chava finally gathers the courage to ask Tevye to allow her marriage to the Russian boy Fyedka, but marrying outside the Jewish faith is unacceptable to him, and he forbids her to see him again. The next day, Chava and Fyedka secretly elope, and Chava is disowned by her family.

question: What musical system does Harold Hill subscribe to in The Music Man?
answerDescription: Hill tells the band they will learn to play by using the "Think System". According to this system, if they simply think of a tune over and over, they will eventually know how to play it without ever touching their instruments.

question: What new song was added to Beauty and the Beast when Toni Braxton joined the Broadway production in 1998?
answerDescription: An entirely new song entitled "A Change in Me" was written specially for Toni Braxton when the R&B singer joined the production in the role of Belle, and has been included in the musical ever since.

question: What was the first Broadway musical with an all-female creative team?
answerDescription: Waitress premiered at the Brooks Atkinson Theatre on Broadway in April 2016, becoming the first Broadway musical with an all-female creative team: book by Jessie Nelson, music and lyrics by Sara Bareilles, direction by Diane Paulus, and choreography by Lorin Latarro. "It's a historic and long overdue moment for Broadway," said Paulus in a statement, "and I'm honored to be working alongside such passionate and inspiring women."

question: What costume does the Phantom wear to the masquerade ball in The Phantom of the Opera?
answerDescription: The Phantom, who has been conspicuously absent since the chandelier disaster, suddenly reappears in costume as the Red Death.

question: In Hamilton, King George III sings that he will send a fully-armed battalion to remind the colonists of ________.
answerDescription: GEORGE III: Oceans rise, empire fallWe have seen each other through it allAnd when push comes to shoveI will send a fully armed battalion to remind you of my love

question: In West Side Story, what terms do both gangs agree to for the rumble?
answerDescription: Tony suggests "a fair fight"--fists only, no weapons. Both leaders agree, despite protests from some members. But at the rumble, things go south quickly, and knives are drawn.

question: What is A Chorus Line based on?
answerDescription: The musical was formed from several taped interview sessions with Broadway dancers, known as "gypsies." When the musical got picked up by Joseph Papp at the Public Theatre, the original dancers had to audition to play themselves in the final version--and not all of them got the job.

question: What was Ludwig van Beethoven's final complete symphony?
answerDescription: Symphony No. 9 in D minor is regarded by many critics as one of Beethoven's greatest works and one of the supreme achievements in the history of western music.

question: What violinist was rumored to have sold his soul to the devil?
answerDescription: At the height of his fame and fortune, Niccolò Paganini (1782-1840) was considered the greatest violinist in the world. In fact, he was such a gifted musician that some people actually believed that he'd sold his soul to the devil for his talent. The rumors of his association with the devil were so persistent that when he died, the Catholic Church denied his body a Catholic burial.

question: What game did Mozart like to play while he composed symphonies?
answerDescription: Mozart loved to play Billiards, and would sometimes play all night, composing symphonies as he played.

question: Which of Bach's organ pieces is often associated with Halloween?
options: PASSACAGLIA AND FUGUE IN C MINOR
FANTASIA AND FUGUE IN C MINOR
PRELUDE AND FUGUE IN A MINOR
TOCCATA AND FUGUE IN D MINOR
answerDescription: It wasn't until the 20th century that Bach's Toccata and Fugue in D minor eclipsed all of his other organ compositions in popularity, thanks in large part to Hollywood producers who began using its thundering organ sounds as a ghoulish shorthand for cinematic terror.

question: Why was Renaissance composer Orlande de Lassus kidnapped three times as a child?
answerDescription: Little is known of Orlande de Lassus' childhood, except that he was kidnapped three times because of the singular beauty of his singing voice. By the end of the 16th century, he had become one of the most famous and influential musicians in Europe.

question: What French instrument is the clarinet descended from?
answerDescription: Johann Christoph Denner is generally credited with inventing the clarinet in Germany around the year 1700 by adding a register key to the chalumeau, a French instrument with a cylindrical bore and eight tone holes. Over time, additional keywork and airtight pads were added to improve the tone and playability.

question: Who composed the music for The Nutcracker?
answerDescription: Tchaikovsky's famous ballets (Swan Lake, The Nutcracker and Sleeping Beauty) have some of the best known tunes in all of romantic music.

question: Which composer kept a frog figurine in his pocket?
answerDescription: Edvard Grieg (1843-1907) had a collection of small dolls and one of them, a "lucky frog," was his concert companion. Before stepping onto the stage as a pianist or a conductor, he would rub the lucky frog in his pocket for good luck.

question: Bach and Handel were both _____.
options: CONVICTED OF PLAGIARIZING THE SAME SYMPHONY
answerDescription: The beautiful strains of George Frideric Handel's "Messiah" and Johann Sebastian Bach's "Christmas Oratorio" evoke a very different picture from the dark bond the two composers shared: Each was blinded by botched cataract surgery at the hands of the great charlatan Chevalier Taylor. Handel survived the surgery at least, but a post-operative infection likely killed Bach.

question: What famous composer has two skulls in his tomb?
answerDescription: After his burial in 1809, Joseph Haydn's head was stolen by phrenologists and a replacement skull was left in his tomb. In 1954, the real skull was finally returned, but the substitute was not removed, and Haydn's tomb now contains both skulls.

question: Who completed Mozart's Requiem, which remained unfinished at the time of his death?
answerDescription: After the production of The Magic Flute, Mozart worked feverishly on his Requiem, with the foreboding that it would commemorate his own death, but he died at the age of 35 without finishing it. The work was completed by his pupil Franz Süssmayr at the request of Mozart's wife, Constanze, after Joseph Eybler, another pupil whom she had asked to complete it, failed to follow through.

question: Marc Antoine Charpentier wrote an opera about a man transformed into a _____.
answerDescription: The plot of Actéon is based on a story in Ovid's Metamorphoses. It tells the story of a hunter who accidentally discovers the goddess Diana bathing with her attendants. He tries to hide but is discovered by Diana who angrily transforms him into a stag, after which he is pursued and torn apart by his own hounds.

question: How big was the world's largest orchestra?
answerDescription: The world's largest orchestra consisted of 8,097 musicians who gathered in Saint Petersburg, Russia, on 1 September 2019, to perform the Russian National Anthem.

question: How many pieces of wood are there in a modern violin?
answerDescription: A single violin is made from over 70 individual pieces of wood.

question: Which composer invented the chorale concerto?
answerDescription: Michael Praetorius (1571-1621) was one of the most versatile composers of his age, being particularly significant in the development of musical forms based on Protestant hymns. His development of the chorale concerto, particularly the polychoral variety, resulted directly from his familiarity with the music of such Venetians as Giovanni Gabrieli and eventually evolved into the chorale cantata, which culminated in the works of J.S. Bach and became a popular liturgical form in Germany for more than a hundred years.

question: What church did Bach write much of his music for?
answerDescription: He composed music for the principal Lutheran churches of Leipzig, composing hundreds of four-part harmonizations of Lutheran chorales, as well as several masses, including Mass in B minor, which is among his most popular vocal works.

question: What musical technique is most closely associated with Richard Wagner's operas?
answerDescription: One of Wagner's greatest gifts to music was the leitmotif. Simply put, it's a musical signature designed to represent a particular character or theme, and he uses the device throughout his operas. Modern film composers have since adopted the technique, and examples can be found in countless Hollywood scores.

question: What is the smallest clarinet?
answerDescription: The smallest clarinet is the Ab Piccolo Clarinet checking in at just 14 inches long. It is called the Ab sopranino and is the only surviving member of the piccolo group.

question: Which Austrian composer was nicknamed "Little Mushroom" by his friends?
answerDescription: Schubert, who was little more than five feet tall, was nicknamed "Schwammerl", which translates as "Little Mushroom". He wasn't little in the music world, however, leaving behind a vast oeuvre, including more than 600 secular vocal works, seven complete symphonies, sacred music, operas, incidental music and a large body of piano and chamber music.

question: What was Gioachino Rossini reportedly doing when he wrote the aria 'Di Tanti Palpiti'?
options: WAITING FOR FOOD AT A RESTAURANT
answerDescription: Rossini wrote the aria 'Di Tanti Palpiti' while waiting for some risotto in a Venice restaurant.

question: What instrument is David Oistrakh mostly associated with?
answerDescription: David Oistrakh was a renowned Soviet classical violinist.

question: Which singer recorded the first country song to sell one million copies?
answerDescription: Vernon Dalhart's 1924 recording of "The Wreck of the Old 97", a classic American ballad about the derailment of Fast Mail train No. 97 near Danville, Virginia in 1903, sold a staggering 7 million copies, alerting national record companies to the existence of a sizable market for country-music vocals.

question: Which country singer was known as "The Singing Brakeman"?
answerDescription: Before rising to fame in the late 1920s, Jimmie Rodgers worked as a brakeman on the New Orleans and Northeastern Railroad, a position formerly held by his oldest brother, Walter, who had been promoted to conductor.

question: Who recorded two of his best-selling albums in prison?
answerDescription: Cash's most popular and best-selling albums were the live albums he recorded in prisons: namely, Johnny Cash at Folsom Prison in 1968 and Johnny Cash at San Quentin in 1969. Throughout his career, he performed in prisons, sympathetic to the plight of inmates who ran afoul of society. Although he himself was arrested seven times on a variety of charges, he only spent a few nights in jail.

question: Which Loretta Lynn song inspired a 1980 biographical film of the same name?
answerDescription: "Coal Miner's Daughter" tells the true story of Lynn's life growing up in rural Kentucky "in a cabin on a hill in Butcher Holler", while her father, Melvin "Ted" Webb, worked all night in the Van Lear coal mine.

question: Which Hank Williams song was released posthumously?
options: "NEVER AGAIN (WILL I KNOCK ON YOUR DOOR)"
answerDescription: "Your Cheatin' Heart" was released in January 1953, about a month after Williams' driver found him dead in the back seat of his car during a stop on the way to a New Year's show in Canton, Ohio. The song became an instant hit, reaching number one on Billboard's Country & Western chart, where it remained for six weeks.

question: Which singer holds the record for largest indoor concert in North America?
answerDescription: At his 2014 the Cowboy Rides Away Tour finale in Arlington, Texas, George Strait broke the Rolling Stones' record for the largest indoor concert when 104,793 fans crowded into AT&T Stadium.

question: Which future country music artist witnessed one of Johnny Cash's San Quentin concerts firsthand ... as an inmate?
answerDescription: While at San Quentin, Merle Haggard played for the prison's country music band. He attributed a performance by Johnny Cash at the prison on New Year's Day 1959 as his main inspiration to pursue a musical career. In 1972, after Haggard had become an established country music star, then-California governor Ronald Reagan granted him a full and unconditional pardon for his past crimes.

question: Which Mississippi Delta queen knocked the Beatles from the top of the charts in 1967?
answerDescription: Bobby Gentry's "Ode to Billie Joe", released on July 10, 1967, was a number-one hit in the US within three weeks of release. The song's popularity proved so enduring that in 1976, nine years after its release, Warner Bros. commissioned author Herman Raucher to expand and adapt the story as a novel and screenplay.

question: Which country singer inspired legends of a bizarre yodeling monster in Kenya?
answerDescription: The Kipsigis tribe in Kenya first heard Jimmie Rodgers' music from British soldiers during World War II. Believing his yodeling to be the work of some sort of antelope-human hybrid creature, the Kipsingis wrote a song called "Chemirocha" to celebrate this bizarre yodeling monster.

question: Which city is considered the Country Music Capital of the World?
answerDescription: Nashville is home to the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum, the annual four-day CMA Music Festival and the famous Grand Ole Opry, just to name a few.

question: Which country star sang The Dukes of Hazzard theme song?
answerDescription: Waylon Jennings not only wrote and sang the theme song "Good Ol' Boys" but also provided narration for the show and even played himself in one episode.

question: Willie Nelson write "On the Road Again" on _______.
answerDescription: During a flight to Hollywood, the producers of the movie Honeysuckle Rose approached Willie about writing a song for the movie, in which he played a country singer juggling his music career with his reponsibilities to his wife and son. About 45 minutes later, Nelson had finished the lyrics ... on one of the airline's barf bags.

question: Who originally recorded Garth Brooks' 1991 hit "The Thunder Rolls"?
answerDescription: "The Thunder Rolls" was originally recorded by Tanya Tucker, but she didn't release the song until it appeared on her self-titled 1995 box set. Her version included a fourth verse which Brooks himself intended to use on his version but cut at the suggestion of producer Allen Reynolds.

question: Which country duo won the Country Music Association Award for top vocal duo every single year from 1972 to 1975?
answerDescription: As a duo, Lynn and Twitty had five consecutive No. 1 hits between 1971 and 1975, including "After the Fire Is Gone" (1971), "Lead Me On" (1971), "Louisiana Woman, Mississippi Man" (1973), "As Soon as I Hang Up the Phone" (1974), and "Feelins'" (1974).

question: Who is considered the "Father of Bluegrass"?
answerDescription: The genre derives its name from the band Bill Monroe and the Blue Grass Boys. Monroe characterized the genre as: "Scottish bagpipes and ole-time fiddlin'. It's Methodist and Holiness and Baptist. It's blues and jazz, and it has a high lonesome sound."

question: Which singer/songwriter reportedly landed a helicopter on Johnny Cash's lawn to hand deliver a music demo?
answerDescription: Eager to kick-start his career, Kristofferson borrowed a helicopter from one of his odd jobs, landed on Johnny Cash's lawn and hand-delivered his demo to the Man in Black himself. One of the songs on that demo, "Sunday Morning Coming Down," became a massive hit for Cash and won Kristofferson Songwriter of the Year honors at the CMAs.

question: Which country music singer parlayed the success of his 1961 hit "Big Bad John" into a sausage empire?
answerDescription: Jimmy Dean rose to fame for his 1961 country music crossover hit "Big Bad John", but today he is perhaps better known for the Jimmy Dean Sausage Company that he founded with his brother Don in 1969. The company did well in part because of Dean's own extemporized, humorous commercials.

question: Which singer was only 4'11"?
answerDescription: Little Jimmy Dickens was known for his diminutive stature and his rhinestone-studded outfits, which he is given credit for introducing into live country music performances. He first performed at the Grand Old Opry in 1948 and remained a fixture on the Opry stage for the next 70 years, making his last performance just days before his death at the age of 95.

question: What variety show was hosted by country singers Buck Owens and Roy Clark?
answerDescription: Inspired by Rowan & Martin's Laugh-In, with the major difference being that Hee Haw was centered on rural rather than pop culture, the show was equally well known for its corn pone humor as for its voluptuous, scantily clad women (called the Hee Haw Honeys) in stereotypical farmer's daughter outfits.

question: Where was Shania Twain born?
answerDescription: Born in Windsor, Ontario, Shania Twain has sold over 100 million records, making her the best-selling female artist in country music history.

question: Which Dolly Parton song reached number one on the Billboard Hot Country Songs chart not once, but twice?
answerDescription: "I Will Always Love You", written as a farewell to her former partner and mentor Porter Wagoner, first reached number one in June 1974, and then in October 1982, with Dolly's re-recording on the soundtrack of the movie version of The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas.

question: What pseudonym did Hank Williams use to record a number of gospel songs?
answerDescription: Although the pseudonym was meant to distinguish Williams' gospel recordings from his more popular country music, Williams insisted on performing his "Luke the Drifter" songs during his regular concerts.

question: What was Hank Williams real name?
answerDescription: By the time Hank arrived in Montgomery in 1937, he had decided to drop his given name, Hiram, in favor of Hank. According to one of his first steel guitarists, Boots Harris, he'd say that "there was a fence outside his house and he'd sleep with the window open, and there was an old cat walking up and down that fence yowling 'H-a-r-r-m-m, h-a-r-r-m-m.' He said he thought the cat was calling him so he changed his name to Hank." The truth was, of course, that "Hank" sounded more like the name of a western music star than "Hiram."

question: Who is the only country female solo act to have a No. 1 hit in four straight decades?
answerDescription: Reba had No. 1 hits in the 1980s, '90s, '00s, and '10s.

question: Which singer rose to stardom following the release of her version of the Bill Mack song "Blue"?
answerDescription: The song became a multi-platinum hit for LeAnn Rimes in 1996. Although it was claimed that Mack had been waiting nearly four decades to find the right vocalist to record "Blue", the song had been previously recorded by at least five artists, including Mack himself in 1958.

question: Which country star created the fictional rock persona Chris Gaines to explore other musical styles?
answerDescription: Initially, Brooks planned to feature the Gaines persona in The Lamb, a motion picture which never materialized. In 1999, Brooks released one album as Gaines; the album produced two charting Billboard singles, including the Top 5 pop hit "Lost in You".

question: What sound did Buck Owens pioneer?
answerDescription: Named in honor of Bakersfield, California, Owens' adopted home, Bakersfield was the first genre of country music to be significantly influenced by rock and roll, and as a result, the first to rely heavily on electric instrumentation and a defined backbeat. It was also a reaction against the slickly produced, orchestra-laden Nashville sound, which was becoming popular in the late 1950s.

question: Why did Reba McEntire almost miss her Grande Ole Opry debut?
answerDescription: For some reason, Reba's name never made it onto the list of performers for the evening. At the door, security wouldn't let her in! (Remember, in 1977, she was still an unknown.) Thankfully, Reba's booking agent came to the rescue and got her inside to play the show.

question: When country music singer Charley Pride played professional baseball, what did the Louisville Clippers trade him for?
answerDescription: While playing in the Negro Leagues with the Louisville Clippers, Pride and Jesse Mitchell were traded to the Birmingham Black Barons for a team bus. In his 1994 autobiography, Pride mused, "Jesse and I may have the distinction of being the only players in history to be traded for a used motor vehicle."

question: Which country music star died in a plane crash on March 5, 1963?
answerDescription: On March 5, 1963, country music stars Patsy Cline, Cowboy Copas, and Hawkshaw Hawkins were killed in an airplane crash near Camden, Tennessee. The owner and pilot of the aircraft, Patsy Cline's manager and the son-in-law of Cowboy Copas, was an inexperienced pilot with a total flight time of just 160 hours.

question: Who did Hank Williams' wife marry shortly after his death?
answerDescription: In October 1952, just a few months before his death, Williams married fellow singer Billie Jean Jones, who he met through her then-boyfriend, singer Faron Young. A year later, Billie Jean married another country star, Johnny Horton. After Horton's death in 1959, Billie Jean briefly dated Johnny Cash.

question: How many of Loretta Lynn's songs have been banned by radio stations?
answerDescription: Loretta had 14 songs banned during her legendary career because of controversial subjects such as birth control ("The Pill"), repeated childbirth ("One's on the Way"), double standards for men and women ("Rated "X""), and being widowed by the draft during the Vietnam War ("Dear Uncle Sam").

question: Which singer is the son of a former MLB pitcher?
answerDescription: Tim McGraw is the son of former MLB pitcher Tug McGraw who was the last active big league player to play under legendary manager Casey Stengel.

question: What was Dolly Parton's first No. 1 single?
answerDescription: Parton received her first Grammy nomination in the Best Country Female Vocal category for "Joshua", losing to Lynn Anderson.

question: What was Tim McGraw's first duet with Faith Hill?
options: "JUST TO HEAR YOU SAY THAT YOU LOVE ME"
answerDescription: The music video for It's Your Love showcases Hill, who is very noticeably pregnant with the couple's first daughter, Gracie.

question: The Dixie Chicks ignited a firestorm of controversy by criticizing which U.S. president?
answerDescription: On March 10, 2003, during a London concert, nine days before the 2003 invasion of Iraq, lead vocalist Natalie Maines told the audience: "We don't want this war, this violence, and we're ashamed that the President of the United States (George W. Bush) is from Texas," which garnered a positive reaction from the British audience but led to public protests and boycotts in the United States.

question: What song did Johnny Cash open most of his concerts with?
answerDescription: He traditionally began his concerts by simply introducing himself, "Hello, I'm Johnny Cash," followed by his signature song "Folsom Prison Blues". The song combines elements from two popular folk styles, the train song and the prison song, both of which Cash continued to use for the rest of his career.

question: To what childhood illness did Patsy Cline attribute her booming voice?
answerDescription: At age 13, Cline was hospitalized with a throat infection and rheumatic fever. Speaking of the incident in 1957 she said, "The fever affected my throat and when I recovered I had this booming voice like Kate Smith's."

question: In the "Six Degrees of Kevin Bacon" game, Reba McEntire has a "Bacon number" of ____.
answerDescription: Reba made her acting debut as Heather Gummer in Tremors, a film in which Bacon also starred.

question: What did Garth Brooks offer to donate to fellow country music artist Chris LeDoux?
answerDescription: When news spread that LeDoux needed a transplant, Brooks quietly offered to donate a portion of his own liver. Although Brooks' liver was incompatible, LeDoux was able to undergo a transplant in 2000 and release two more albums before dying of cancer in 2005.

question: What was the name of Merle Haggard's backup band?
answerDescription: Between 1969 and 1987 the Strangers were voted Band of the Year by the Academy of Country Music eight times--more than any other group in history.

question: In which song does Hank Williams sing: "I got a hot rod ford and a two dollar bill"?
answerDescription: Williams performed "Hey, Good Lookin" on the Kate Smith Evening Hour on March 26, 1952. The appearance remains one of the few existing film clips of the singer performing live. He is introduced by Roy Acuff and banters with a young June Carter, wearing his famous white cowboy suit adorned in musical notes.

question: Where did George Strait elope with his high school sweetheart?
answerDescription: Seven months after eloping to Mexico with Norma Voss, Strait remarried her in Texas to satisfy their parents.

question: Which singer did Dolly Parton replace on The Porter Wagoner Show?
answerDescription: Initially, much of Wagoner's audience was unhappy that Norma Jean had left the show and was reluctant to accept Parton (sometimes chanting loudly for Norma Jean from the audience). But with Wagoner's assistance, Dolly soon won over the crowd and became a fan favorite herself.

question: In which song does George Jones sing: "He had underlined in red every single 'I love you'"?
answerDescription: "He Stopped Loving Her Today" tells the story of a man who keeps old letters from an ex lover in the hopes that she'll come back. The song reaches its peak in the chorus, revealing that the woman does return finally--for his funeral.

question: How long did Willie Nelson's 1978 album Stardust stay on Billboard Top Country Albums Chart?
answerDescription: Stardust remained on the Top Country Albums Chart for 540 weeks -- that's 10 consecutive years!

question: Who helped Jimmie Rodgers write many of his songs?
answerDescription: His sister-in-law, Elsie McWilliams, was his most frequent collaborator. Rodgers could not read music, so McWilliams would play the songs and he would learn them by ear. She was the first woman to make a career as a country music songwriter and was inducted into the Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame in 1979.

question: What disease damaged Shania Twain's vocal cords?
answerDescription: Twain lost her voice for several years after being diagnosed with Lyme disease, the most common tick-borne illness in the U.S. After a pair of surgeries, she was able to return to performing.

question: Which actress did Kenny Chesney marry in 2005?
answerDescription: Renée Zellweger and Kenny Chesney took the world by surprise when they got married after knowing each other for five months. But it was perhaps even more surprising when the two decided to have the marriage annulled just four months later. Zellweger cited fraud as the reason in the related papers, and after media scrutiny of her use of the word "fraud", she qualified the use of the term, stating that it was "simply legal language and not a reflection of Kenny's character." Chesney later commented, "The only fraud that was committed was me thinking that I knew what it was like ... that I really understood what it was like to be married, and I really didn't."

question: Carrie Underwood got her start on which reality TV show?
answerDescription: She rose to fame as the winner of the fourth season of American Idol in 2005.

question: What is widely regarded as the first hip hop record?
answerDescription: The Sugarhill Gang's "Rapper's Delight" is credited for introducing hip hop music to a wide audience, reaching the top 40 in the United States, as well as the top 3 in the UK and number-one in Canada.

question: How many albums did The Notorious B.I.G. release before his death?
answerDescription: He released only one album, Ready to Die (1994), before he was murdered in a drive-by shooting. Sixteen days after his death, Biggie's double-disc second album was released as planned with the shortened title of Life After Death and hit No. 1 on the Billboard 200 charts.

question: What name did Lil Wayne go by originally?
answerDescription: Yup. Before Dwayne Michael Carter Jr. was known as Lil Wayne, Weezy, or Tunechi, he called himself Shrimp Daddy, with inspiration for the pseudonym coming from former Cash Money artist Pimp Daddy.

question: Which rapper is known for her alter egos, which include "Cookie", "Harajuku Barbie", and "Roman Zolanski"?
answerDescription: With her parents frequently fighting during her childhood, Minaj lived through characters she created as a means of escape. Her first identity was Cookie, who became Harajuku Barbie and (later) Nicki Minaj. For Pink Friday, Minaj created another alter ego: Roman Zolanski, "a demon inside her", Minaj's "twin brother" whose character she assumes when she is angry. Roman has been compared to Eminem's alter ego Slim Shady, and on "Roman's Revenge" Minaj and Eminem collaborate as their alter egos.

question: How many copies of Eminem's debut album Infinite did he sell?
answerDescription: Sales for the album, which he recorded for the independent Web Entertainment label, were not ... ummm ... infinite. In fact, he only sold about 1,000 copies. But poor sales and indifferent reviews led him to craft the angrier, moodier tracks for which he would become famous.

question: What was the name of Snoop Dogg's debut album?
answerDescription: The distinctive sounds of Doggystyle helped introduce the hip-hop subgenre of g-funk to a mainstream audience.

question: Who did Jay-Z diss in his song "Takeover"?
answerDescription: Nas responded with "Ether", in which he compared Jay-Z to such characters as J.J. Evans from the sitcom Good Times and cigarette company mascot Joe Camel.

question: What form of vocal percussion is common in hip hop?
answerDescription: Beatboxing is connected with hip-hop culture, often referred to as "the fifth element" of hip-hop, although it is not limited to hip-hop music.

question: What does the "B" in Cardi B stand for?
answerDescription: "My sister's name is Hennessy," the rapper explained to talk show host Jimmy Fallon. "So everyone used to call me Bacardi, and I started calling myself Bacardi," which eventually was shortened to Cardi B.

question: Which rapper is famous for wearing parachute pants?
answerDescription: After breaking onto the hip-hop scene in 1990 with the chart-topping tune "U Can't Touch This", MC Hammer became synonymous with the flashy pants--billowy trousers that droop in the crotch and taper to the lower leg. But don't call them parachute pants in his presence. "I detest the term," he told Racked in 2016. "They're called Hammer pants."

question: Which hip hop single is an early example of turntablilsm?
options: "THE ADVENTURES OF GRANDMASTER FLASH ON THE WHEELS OF STEEL"
answerDescription: "The Adventures of Grandmaster Flash on the Wheels of Steel", a single released by Grandmaster Flash in 1981, is a live DJ mix recording of Flash scratching and mixing records from various groups using three turntables.

question: Which rapper attempted suicide at the age of 12?
answerDescription: In the outro of "Let It All Work Out", Wayne opens up about the self-inflicted gunshot wound when he was just 12 years old: "I aimed where my heart was pounding / I shot it, and I woke up with blood all around me / It's mine, I didn't die, but as I was dying / God came to my side and we talked about it / He sold me another life and he made a prophet."

question: What rapper holds the world record for most words in a hit single?
answerDescription: The Detroit rapper achieved a world record with "Rap God". The six-minute track contains 1,560 words which means that Eminem is rapping a tongue-twisting 4.28 words per second.

question: Which rapper was controversially removed from the Billboard Hot Country Songs chart in 2019?
answerDescription: Lil Nas X came to international attention for his country rap single "Old Town Road", which debuted on the Hot Country Songs chart at number 19. But the rapper's career on the country chart was short-lived. Billboard controversially removed the song from the chart in March 2019, telling Rolling Stone: "When determining genres, a few factors are examined, but first and foremost is musical composition. While "Old Town Road" incorporates references to country and cowboy imagery, it does not embrace enough elements of today's country music to chart in its current version."

question: Which rapper claimed to have slept with The Notorious B.I.G.'s wife in the 1996 diss track "Hit 'Em Up"?
answerDescription: 2Pac not only attacked Biggie's street cred, but claimed to have slept with his wife. "Hit 'Em Up" had a large role in exacerbating the East Coast-West Coast hip hop rivalry, and Shakur was murdered in a drive-by shooting just three months after its release.

question: What did Snoop Dogg change his name to in 2012?
answerDescription: In 2012, after a trip to Jamaica, Snoop announced a conversion to Rastafarianism and told reporters he had been rechristened Snoop Lion by a Rastafarian priest in Jamaica. As Snoop Lion he released a reggae album, Reincarnated, and a documentary film of the same name, about his Jamaican experience. His 13th studio album, Bush, was released in May 2015 and marked a return of the Snoop Dogg name.

question: Who did Jay-Z marry in 2008?
answerDescription: Their relationship became a matter of public record on April 22, 2008, but Beyoncé did not publicly debut her $5 million Lorraine Schwartz-designed wedding ring until the Fashion Rocks concert on September 5, 2008.

question: What is the name of Eminem's alter ego?
answerDescription: Slim Shady is the evil and mischievous side of Eminem. He was created when Mathers joined the rap group D12, or the Dirty Dozen. Since there were supposed to be 12 rappers and they only had six, they each came up with an alter ego, and Slim Shady was born. When Eminem raps through the point of view of Slim, his songs are violent and dark, with a comic twist.

question: Which dance craze is Nicki Minaj closely associated with?
answerDescription: Nicki is an expert twerker, as evidenced by appearances in music videos such as Busta Rhymes' "Twerk It", Robin Thicke's "Shakin' It 4 Daddy", Big Sean's "Dance (A$$)", and Wale's "Clappers".

question: What was the first hip hop group to win an Academy Award for best original song?
answerDescription: In 2006 Three 6 Mafia won the Academy Award for Best Original Song at the 78th Academy Awards for their song "It's Hard out Here for a Pimp" from the film Hustle & Flow, in which Terrence Howard stars as a Memphis hustler aspiring to become a rapper.

question: Which rapper has the most face tattoos?
answerDescription: When it comes to face tattoos, Lil Wayne is a pioneer. He has more than 25 tattoos on his face, including "I AM MUSIC" over his eye, "Fear" and "God" over his eyelids, the number "17" on the side of his face, "BAKED" on his forehead, teardrops under both his eyes, a flower on his ear, and nine stars on the side of his face under the word "Misunderstood". His most recent additions include an Arabic scripture above his left eyebrow and a giant eye on his chin. The Arabic tattoo is meant to read Momma's boy, but according to Arabic speakers, it actually reads kid and my mother.

question: Who gave Drake a lapdance in her infamous "Anaconda" video?
answerDescription: The internet almost exploded when it saw the wild lapdance Nicki Minaj gave Drake in her "Anaconda" video. Afterwards, he took to Twitter to confirm that he was happy he was selected for the cameo. "Def the best invite to a video shoot EVER. #ViewsFromMyChair #MyAnacondaWasWayUp"

question: What neurological disorder does Lil Wayne suffer from?
answerDescription: In a 2013 interview with DJ Felli Fel of Power 106 in Los Angeles, Wayne revealed that he suffers from epilepsy: "This isn't my first, second, third, fourth, fifth, sixth or seventh seizure. I've had a bunch of seizures. Y'all just never hear about them. But this time, it got real bad because I had three of them in a row."

question: What rapper ran for President of the United States in 2020?
answerDescription: On July 4, 2020, Kanye West announced on Twitter that he would be running in the 2020 presidential election. On July 7, he was interviewed by Forbes about his presidential run and confirmed that he would run as an independent under the "Birthday Party", explaining that he chose the name "Because when we win, it's everybody's 'birthday'." Skeptics have suggested that his presidential run may have been a publicity stunt to promote his latest music. West responded to these critics by announcing that he would run again in 2024.

question: What virtual world did Travis Scott perform live shows in?
answerDescription: Scott performed five virtual live shows in the video game Fortnite Battle Royale from April 23 to 25, 2020 with visuals based on his Astroworld tour. It received more than 27 million viewers and boosted the sales of Fortnite-branded Cactus Jack products.

question: What album did Tupac Shakur release from prison?
answerDescription: Released while 2Pac was imprisoned, Me Against the World made an immediate impact on the charts, debuting at number one on the Billboard 200 and holding the top spot for four consecutive weeks. It is now hailed as his magnum opus and commonly ranks among the greatest, most influential rap albums.

question: Who holds the world record for longest freestyle rap?
answerDescription: Harvey "FRZY" Daniels unofficially set the Guinness world record for longest freestyle rap on January 12, 2020, when he went 31 hours straight!

question: Who won the first Grammy for Best Rap Performance?
options: DJ JAZZY JEFF & THE FRESH PRINCE
answerDescription: DJ Jazzy Jeff & The Fresh Prince won Best Rap Performance for their 1988 hit "Parents Just Don't Understand" but decided to boycott the ceremony after finding out the Grammys would not air their category on television.

question: In "Money", Cardi B sings: "I was born to _____."
answerDescription: "I was born to flexDiamonds on my neckI like boardin' jets, I like mornin' sexBut nothing in this world that I like more than checks"

question: What is Ice Cube's real name?
answerDescription: Ice Cube was born O'Shea Jackson on June 15, 1969, in South Central Los Angeles, California.

question: How long did it take Young Thug to write his hit single "Danny Glover"?
answerDescription: "I can't remember 16 bars," Thug noted in a 2015 interview. "I just do it bar for bar. I did a song in eight minutes. I thought everybody could write songs that fast. But working with a lot of them, they don't. Wayne and Drake, it takes them so long to do a song. I understand why, because they want it to be perfect. But I think I can do a perfect song in ten minutes. I did 'Danny Glover' in eight minutes. 'Stoner' took me almost an hour."

question: Who is usually credited with being the first female MC?
answerDescription: Sharon Green, a.k.a. MC Sha-Rock, began as a local b-girl, or breakdancer, in the earliest days of South Bronx hip hop scene and culture in the late 1970s but went on to become a founding member of the Funky Four Plus One. Within the hip-hop community she has been referred to as the "Mother of the Mic".

question: What was Lauryn Hill's nickname in the Fugees?
answerDescription: Within the group, she picked up the nickname "L. Boogie" for her lyrical skills.

question: What city is considered the birthplace of jazz?
answerDescription: Jazz originated in the African-American communities of New Orleans in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

question: Who coined the term "jazz"?
answerDescription: The earliest written record of the word is in a 1912 article in the Los Angeles Times in which a minor league baseball pitcher described a pitch which he called a "jazz ball" "because it wobbles and you simply can't do anything with it".

question: Jazz is characterized by ______.
answerDescription: Jazz is characterized by swing and blue notes, call and response vocals, polyrhythms and improvisation.

question: Who is sometimes referred to as the Queen of Jazz?
answerDescription: Ella Fitzgerald was an American singer noted for her purity of tone, impeccable diction, phrasing, intonation, and a "horn-like" improvisational ability.

question: What instrument did Miles Davis play?
answerDescription: Rolling Stone described him as "the most revered jazz trumpeter of all time."

question: According to scientists, what part of the brain do jazz musicians turn on when they improvise?
answerDescription: According to a study conducted by two professors from John Hopkins University, when jazz musicians improvise, their brains turn off the dorsolateral prefrontal and lateral orbital regions linked to self-censoring, inhibition and introspection, and turn on the medial prefrontal cortex--the part of the brain that lets self-expression flow.

question: What jazz soloist was known as "Yardbird"?
answerDescription: Parker acquired the nickname "Yardbird" early in his career, inspiring the titles of a number of his compositions, including "Yardbird Suite", "Ornithology", "Bird Gets the Worm", and "Bird of Paradise".

question: Which pianist was dismissed by jazz critic Philip Larkin as "the elephant on the keyboard"?
answerDescription: While acclaimed by many, Monk's unorthodox approach to the piano, which combines a highly percussive attack with abrupt, dramatic use of switched key releases, silences, and hesitations, is not universally appreciated.

question: Which jazz trumpeter had to develop a new embouchure late in his career because of a mouth injury?
answerDescription: After suffering a dental injury in an altercation with an acquaintance trying to extort money, Baker had to be fitted for dentures and relearn how to play the trumpet.

question: When was the Jazz Age?
answerDescription: Jazz was so popular in the 1920s that the time period is often called the "Jazz Age" by historians.

question: When is International Jazz Day celebrated?
answerDescription: International Jazz Day, celebrated annually on April 30, is an International Day declared by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization in 2011 "to highlight jazz and its diplomatic role of uniting people in all corners of the globe."

question: What nightclub did Thelonious Monk first perform at?
answerDescription: Minton's is famous for its role in the development of modern jazz. During the early 1940s, its jam sessions featured Monk, Bud Powell, Kenny Clarke, Charlie Parker and Dizzy Gillespie.

question: Jazz developed from roots in _____.
answerDescription: Jazz is hands down the most hybrid form of music in the world, combining elements of brass-band marches, French quadrilles, biguine, ragtime, blues, African rhythms, and even European chamber music.

question: What dance craze was inspired by jazz pianist Spencer Williams?
answerDescription: In 1917, Williams wrote a song called "Shim-Me-Sha-Wabble" which inspired a jazz dance called the shimmy.

question: What was jazz trumpeter Louis Armstrong's nickname?
answerDescription: One of the most influential figures in the history of jazz, Armstrong was nicknamed Satchmo, Satch, and Pops. His career spanned five decades, from the 1920s to the 1960s.

question: Which jazz musician was known for playing a bent trumpet?
answerDescription: On January 6, 1953, Gillespie threw a party for his wife Lorraine at Snookie's, a club in Manhattan, where his trumpet's bell got bent upward in an accident. He liked the sound so much he had a special trumpet made with a 45 degree raised bell, which became his trademark.

question: Which Miles Davis song contains 19 edits?
answerDescription: The famous stop-start opening of "Pharaoh's Dance" was constructed entirely in the studio, using repeat loops of certain sections. Later in the track, there are several micro-edits, including a one-second-long fragment that first appears at 8:39 and is repeated five times between 8:54 and 8:59.

question: What kind of flower did Billie Holiday wear onstage?
answerDescription: One night before a performance, Holiday burned her hair with a curling iron. Sylvia Sims, a fellow jazz singer, promptly went to a club down the street where the coat check girls were selling flowers. Sims bought a big white gardenia and gave it to Holiday, who wore it that night to cover her burnt hair. She liked wearing the flower so much that she began to put a gardenia in her hair before every performance.

question: What instrument did John Coltrane experiment with toward the end of his career?
answerDescription: Primarily known for the saxophone, Coltrane experimented with the flute in both live performances and studio recordings toward the end of his career.

question: What was the first jazz composition to win the Pulitzer Prize for Music?
answerDescription: Blood on the Fields is a two-and-a-half-hour jazz oratorio by Wynton Marsalis. It was commissioned by the Lincoln Center and concerns a couple moving from slavery to freedom.

question: What form of jazz did clarinetist Benny Goodman help popularize in the 1930s?
answerDescription: Goodman was known as the "King of Swing".

question: Who sings with Ella Fitzgerald on her recording of "Cheek to Cheek"?
answerDescription: There's absolutely no reason Ella's warm yet ultra-cool voice should blend so effortlessly with Louis Armstrong's gravelly growl. They're the opposite poles of jazz singing. But it's magic.

question: Duke Ellington became famous through his orchestra's appearances at which Harlem club?
answerDescription: Duke Ellington's orchestra was the house band at the Cotton Club from December 4, 1927 until June 30, 1931. The club's wealthy clientele poured in nightly to see them, and a weekly radio broadcast gave Ellington national exposure.

question: What was the first published jazz composition?
answerDescription: Jelly Roll Morton was jazz's first arranger, proving that a genre rooted in improvisation could retain its essential spirit and characteristics when notated. His composition "Jelly Roll Blues" was published in 1915.

question: "So What" is the first track of which Miles Davis album?
answerDescription: Kind of Blue is regarded by many critics as the greatest jazz record of all time.

question: What kind of singing did Louis Armstrong popularize?
answerDescription: He was skilled at scat singing (improvised vocal jazz using nonsensical words) and was among the first to record it, on the Hot Five recording "Heebie Jeebies" in 1926. The recording was so popular that his group became the most famous jazz band in the United States.

question: Which flubbed recording won Ella Fitzgerald a Grammy Award?
answerDescription: Ella in Berlin, one of her best-selling albums, includes a Grammy-winning performance of "Mack the Knife" in which she forgets the lyrics after the first stanza but improvises new lyrics magnificently to compensate.

question: Which Billie Holiday song was named "song of the century" by TIME Magazine?
answerDescription: "Strange Fruit" protests the lynching of Black Americans, which had reached a peak in the Southern United States at the turn of the 20th century, comparing the victims to the fruit of trees. The song has been called "a declaration of war" and "the beginning of the civil rights movement."

question: How many songs did Duke Ellington write?
answerDescription: A master at writing miniatures for the three-minute 78 rpm recording format, Ellington wrote more than one thousand compositions. His extensive body of work is the largest recorded personal jazz legacy, and many of his pieces have become standards.

question: Who was the first violinist to play jazz?
answerDescription: Hezekiah Leroy Gordon Smith, better known as Stuff Smith, was featured in several numbers on the Nat King Cole Trio album, After Midnight. He is also credited as the first violinist to use electric amplification techniques on a violin.

question: Who is considered the "King of Pop"?
answerDescription: On June 25, 2009, the music world stopped spinning when news broke of the death of Michael Jackson. Dubbed the "King of Pop", he is regarded as one of the most significant cultural figures of the 20th century and one of the greatest entertainers in the history of music.

question: Lady Gaga got her stage name from a _____ song.
answerDescription: In May 2006, Stefani Joanne Angelina Germanotta began dating producer Rob Fusari, who claims he was the first person to call her "Lady Gaga", which he derived from the Queen song "Radio Ga Ga".

question: What are Ariana Grande's fans called?
answerDescription: Arianators make up the Ariana Army.

question: Which singer was NOT a Mouseketeer on The All-New Mickey Mouse Club?
answerDescription: The All-New Mickey Mouse Club ran on the Disney Channel from 1989 to 1994 and featured a number of cast members who went on to become big stars, including Britney Spears, Christina Aguilera, and Justin Timberlake.

question: Where did Justin Bieber's talent manager discover him?
answerDescription: Justin's early fanbase developed on YouTube, where he was discovered by a talent manager and signed to RBMG (Raymond Braun Media Group).

question: What pop singer is known as "The Material Girl"?
answerDescription: Madonna became known as "The Material Girl" after her hit single of the same name hit the charts in 1984. She hates it, claiming she would never have done the song if she knew the name would stick.

question: What dance craze did Michael Jackson popularize in 1983?
answerDescription: On May 16, 1983, during a performance of "Billie Jean" on Motown 25: Yesterday, Today, Forever, Jackson appeared in his signature black trousers, silver socks, silver shirt, black-sequined jacket, rhinestoned glove, and black fedora, spun around, posed, and began moonwalking. From that point forward, the moonwalk became Jackson's signature move.

question: Who was rocketed to super-stardom in 1998 by the hit single "Baby One More Time"?
answerDescription: "Baby One More Time" was Britney Spears' first hit. The album sold over 13 million copies in the US and rocketed Britney to super-stardom.

question: Which pop singer wrote the "Like a good neighbor" State Farm jingle?
answerDescription: Before he sang "Mandy", Barry Manilow honed his skills on Madison Avenue, penning brilliant jingles for State Farm "Like a good neighbor, State Farm is there") and Band-Aid ("I am stuck on Band-Aid, 'cause Band-Aid's stuck on me!")

question: Where did Billie Eilish record her first studio album?
answerDescription: When We Fall Asleep, Where Do We Go? was recorded in her brother Finneas' small bedroom studio in Highland Park, Los Angeles. The pair explained that they chose this recording location rather than a professional studio due to the bedroom's intimate and homely nature as well as the manner in which the bedroom affects vocals.

question: Who is the youngest solo artist with a No. 1 hit on the Billboard Hot 100?
answerDescription: In 1963, the single "Fingertips" was a number-one hit on the Billboard Hot 100 when Stevie Wonder was just 13, making him the youngest artist ever to top the chart.

question: What was the title of Taylor Swift's first album?
answerDescription: Her self-titled debut album in 2006 peaked at number five on the Billboard 200 and spent the most weeks on the chart in the 2000s.

question: In which song does Madonna sing: "A man can tell a thousand lies, I've learned my lesson well"?
answerDescription: A man can tell a thousand liesI've learned my lesson wellHope I live to tellThe secret I have learned, 'til thenIt will burn inside of me

question: Which song did Michael Jackson want to sing as a duet with Prince?
answerDescription: Jackson originally envisioned "Bad" as a duet with Prince, pitting the two superstars against each other in a musical duel. Producer Quincy Jones arranged a meeting, but Prince took issue with the song's opening line, "Your butt is mine." He responded to the King of Pop by saying, "Who's singing that to whom? Because you sure ain't singing that to me--and I sure ain't singing that to you."

question: Who was the oldest living artist to top the UK Singles Chart?
answerDescription: The oldest artist to top the UK singles chart was Tom Jones, who was 68 when "(Barry) Islands in the Stream" reached the top in 2009.

question: What prop did Miley Cyrus use in her 2013 MTV Video Music Awards performance with Robin Thicke?
answerDescription: If there's one thing everyone remember about the 2013 MTV VMAs, it's Miley's foam finger. Oh, the utter outrage the world felt over the former Disney Channel star, then 20 years old, acting inappropriately with the foam prop.

question: How big is Mariah Carey's vocal range?
answerDescription: Mariah has a five octave range, with the ability to reach notes beyond the 7th octave. Ron Givens of Entertainment Weekly described it this way: "First, a rippling, soulful ooh comes rolling effortlessly from her throat: alto. Then, after a quick breath, she goes for the stratosphere, with a sound that nearly changes the barometric pressure in the room. In one brief swoop, she seems to squeal and roar at the same time."

question: Which music video shows Madonna sailing the canals of Venice in a gondola?
answerDescription: The "Like a Virgin" music video portrays Madonna sailing down the canals of Venice in a gondola, as well as roaming around a palace wearing a white wedding dress. Scholars have credited "Like a Virgin" as the song which cemented her position as a pop culture icon.

question: For which music video did Michael Jackson develop a gravity-defying lean?
answerDescription: In Jackson's 1987 music video "Smooth Criminal", the legendary performer leans forward 45 degrees from a straight-up position ... and comes back! It's a feat that seemingly defies both physics and physiology. To accomplish this live, Jackson and designers developed a special shoe to lock the performer's feet to the stage, allowing them to lean forward. They were granted U.S. Patent 5,255,452 for the device.

question: What are Barry Manilow fans called?
answerDescription: The Fanilows have been around for quite some time, but really reached a pop culture high when a Will & Grace episode titled "Fanilow" outed Will as a Barry fan.

question: In which song does Whitney Houston sing: "The ride with you was worth the fall my friend"?
answerDescription: The ride with you was worth the fall my friendLoving you makes life worth livingDidn't we almost have it allThe night we held on till the morningYou know you'll never love that way againDidn't we almost have it all

question: What did Prince change his name to in 1993?
answerDescription: In the midst of a contractual dispute with Warner Bros. in 1993, Prince changed his stage name to  an unpronounceable symbol (known to fans as the "Love Symbol"), and was sometimes referred to as "The Artist Formerly Known as Prince" or simply "The Artist". He signed with Arista Records in 1998 and began referring to himself by his own name again in 2000.

question: Whose piano did Mariah Carey buy?
answerDescription: In 1999, Carey bought Marilyn Monroe's white lacquered baby grand piano. She paid over $600,000 for the one-of-a-kind treasure. Mariah has publicly acknowledged Marilyn Monroe as one of her idols, and her daughter Monroe is named after Marilyn.

question: What phrase did Whitney Houston popularize on the reality TV show Being Bobby Brown?
options: "DO I LOOK LIKE BOOBOO THE FOOL?"
answerDescription: Houston popularized the phrase "Hell to the no" on the series and was nominated for a VH-1 "Big In '05 Award" for "Quote of the Year". This phrase also appeared on T-shirts.

question: Which classic rock album is sometimes said to be a soundtrack to The Wizard of Oz?
options: THE DARK SIDE OF THE MOON
answerDescription: Some fans insist that Pink Floyd's The Dark Side of the Moon lines up perfectly with the 1939 film The Wizard of Oz, producing moments where the film and the album appear to correspond with each other. Pink Floyd drummer Nick Mason told MTV in 1997, "It's absolute nonsense. It has nothing to do with The Wizard of Oz. It was all based on The Sound of Music."

question: What did Queen vocalist Freddie Mercury attribute his enhanced vocal range to?
answerDescription: Mercury was born with four extra teeth and attributed his enhanced vocal range to this. He refused to have his teeth fixed, fearing it would affect his vocal ability.

question: What band's lead singer is credited with popularizing stage diving?
answerDescription: There are earlier cases of performers throwing themselves into the crowd, but in the early 1970s, stage diving became a regular occurrence for Iggy Pop of the Stooges, and he is often credited with popularizing the practice.

question: Who is the only member of ZZ Top who doesn't have a beard?
answerDescription: Ironically, the only member of ZZ Top who doesn't have a beard is drummer Frank Beard.

question: Which Beatle crossed Abbey Road barefoot?
answerDescription: In the late 1960s, the rumor started circulating among Beatles fans that Paul had died in a fiery car crash. Because they didn't want to impact the popularity of the band, naturally the other Beatles hired a McCartney look-alike to replace him. But the band felt bad lying to their fans, so they started leaving clues in the album artwork to tip them off. One such "clue" was the cover of the Abbey Road album, in which Paul crosses the street barefoot. Because, of course, the dead need no shoes.

question: Who once kicked Jimi Hendrix out of his band?
answerDescription: Little Richard felt nothing should distract from his star power, and Hendrix was just so distracting with his eccentric style and guitar skills.

question: How many encores did Elvis Presley usually give?
answerDescription: Elvis never gave an encore at his concerts. Instead, the lights would come up and an announcer would say, "Elvis has left the building."

question: What English rock band produced three legendary guitarists: Jeff Beck, Jimmy Page, and Eric Clapton?
answerDescription: The Yardbirds started getting some attention on the burgeoning British rhythm and blues scene when they took over as the house band at the Crawdaddy Club in Richmond, succeeding the Rolling Stones. They would expand into pop, pioneering psychedelic rock and early hard rock, but are best known perhaps for starting the careers of three of rock's most famous guitarists: Eric Clapton, Jimmy Page and Jeff Beck, all of whom ranked in the top five of Rolling Stone magazine's list of 100 greatest guitarists.

question: Which goddess inspired the Rolling Stones' logo?
answerDescription: Known as "Tongue and Lips" or "Hot Lips," the band's famous logo was created by art student John Pasche in 1970. While Jagger requested the likeness of the Hindu goddess Kali, often depicted with a very pronounced mouth with the tongue sticking out, Pasche ended up using the front man's own mouth as his template for the signature logo.

question: The Doors got their name from a book by which author?
answerDescription: The band took its name from the title of Aldous Huxley's book The Doors of Perception, itself derived from a line in William Blake's The Marriage of Heaven and Hell: "If the doors of perception were cleansed, everything would appear to man as it is: infinite."

question: How many times were Linkin Park rejected by record labels?
answerDescription: Linkin Park auditioned and were rejected for record deals 44 times (yes, forty-four) before finally signing with Warner Bros. Records and becoming one of the biggest musical acts of the 2000s. In fact, Warner Brothers rejected Linkin Park three times before finally signing them.

question: Which band got its name by taking the first letter of each band member's name?
answerDescription: ABBA: Agnetha Fältskog, Björn Ulvaeus, Benny Andersson, and Anni-Frid Lyngstad.

question: How many different instruments did Prince play on his debut album?
answerDescription: Prince's first album, For You, was recorded at Record Plant Studios. The album was mixed in Los Angeles and released on April 7, 1978. According to the album notes, Prince wrote, produced, arranged, composed, and played all 27 instruments on the recording.

question: What did Nirvana frontman Kurt Cobain wear to his wedding?
answerDescription: On Feb. 24, 1992, Cobain and Courtney Love got hitched on Waikiki Beach in Hawaii. Cobain wore green pajamas because, as he said at the time, he was "too lazy to put on a tux".

question: In which song does Mick Jagger sing: "Well he can't be a man cause he doesn't smoke the same cigarettes as me"?
answerDescription: When I'm watching my TVAnd a man comes on and tells meHow white my shirts can beWell he can't be a man cause he doesn't smokeThe same cigarettes as meI can't get no, oh no, no, noHey, hey, hey, that's what I sayI can't get no satisfaction

question: Which Pink Floyd recording became the first rock album to be played in space?
options: THE DARK SIDE OF THE MOON
answerDescription: In 1989, Russian cosmonauts took a Pink Floyd album with them to the MIR space station. Sadly, it wasn't The Dark Side of the Moon. It was their 1988 live album Delicate Sound of Thunder, which was the only one of their albums that was officially released in Russia.

question: Who dances with Bruce Springsteen in the music video for "Dancing in the Dark"?
answerDescription: "Dancing in the Dark" was the biggest of seven hit singles from Born in the U.S.A. (1984), peaking at No. 2 on the Billboard singles chart. The video featured a young Courteney Cox dancing on stage with Springsteen, which helped launch her career.

question: How old was Jim Morrison when he died?
answerDescription: On July 3, 1971, he was found dead in the bath at the age of 27--the same age as several other famous rock stars in the 27 Club, including Jimi Hendrix, Janis Joplin, and Kurt Cobain. After Cobain's death, his mother told The Daily World--"Now he's gone and joined that stupid club. I told him not to join that stupid club."

question: What is the only song Led Zeppelin ever recorded with a guest vocalist?
answerDescription: "The Battle of Evermore" is perhaps Led Zeppelin's clearest example of a Tolkien-inspired, nostalgic soundscape that attempts to situate the listener in a spatialized fantasy world. Robert Plant felt he needed another voice to tell the story that plays out in the song, so Sandy Denny from Fairport Convention was brought in. Her vocals represent the people as the town crier, while Plant's voice is the narrator.

question: On March 31, 1967, during a performance at the London Astoria, Jimi Hendrix ____________.
answerDescription: During the show, Hendrix gave an especially dynamic performance before setting his guitar on fire at the end of a 45-minute set. In the wake of the stunt, members of London's press labeled Hendrix the "Black Elvis" and the "Wild Man of Borneo".

question: Why did guitarist Jeremy Spencer leave Fleetwood Mac in 1971?
answerDescription: Jeremy Spencer was Fleetwood Mac's original guitarist and played with the group on its first four albums. Shortly after arriving in LA for a gig at the Whisky A Go Go, Spencer left the band's hotel room to visit a bookshop on Hollywood Boulevard. He did not return, forcing the cancellation of that evening's concert while the band went searching for him. Some days later, he was found to have joined a religious cult called the Children of God, and he declared that he no longer wanted any involvement with Fleetwood Mac.

question: Which hotel chain banned the Who for life?
answerDescription: On 23 August 1967, while on tour with the Who, drummer Keith Moon celebrated his 21st birthday (it was actually his 20th birthday) at a Holiday Inn in Flint, Michigan. As soon as he reached Flint, Moon started drinking. He started a food fight and knocked out part of his front tooth. At the hospital, doctors removed the remainder of the tooth but couldn't give him an anesthetic due to his inebriation. Back at the hotel, Moon began throwing guests and furniture into the pool and started a fire. A piano was reportedly destroyed. Hotel management was furious, presented Moon with a bill for $24,000, and banned the Who from all Holiday Inn properties for life.

question: Imagine Dragons caught their first big break when the lead singer of which band fell sick?
answerDescription: In 2010, Train's frontman fell sick just prior to the Bite of Las Vegas Festival. Imagine Dragons, who at the time were still playing to a lot of empty lounges in Vegas, were called to fill in for them and performed in front of a crowd of more than 26,000 people.

question: Why was Nirvana thrown out of their own record release party for Nevermind?
answerDescription: After a few bottles of Jack Daniels,  bassist Krist Novoselic heaved a tamale at Kurt Cobain, who retaliated with a salvo of guacamole. Soon food was flying with no regard for the industry geeks whose suits were getting splattered. The doormen rounded the band up and got them out the door just in time for them to barf up their drinks on the side of the road. "We were laughing," Novoselic remembers. "Oh my God, we just got kicked out of our own record release party!"

question: What was the name of the airplane Buddy Holly died in?
answerDescription: The airplane that Buddy Holly died in was named American Pie. Don McLean would later write a song about the accident with the same title. The single was a number-one hit in the U.S. for four weeks in 1972.

question: What rock star once broke into Graceland?
answerDescription: Long before he became famous, Bruce Springsteen was caught climbing over the Graceland fence by Harold Lloyd, Elvis' first cousin and a security officer working nights at the mansion. Elvis was not home. Springsteen was promptly escorted off the property.

question: What religious group nearly convinced U2 to break up the band?
answerDescription: Bono's, the Edge's, and Larry Mullen's involvement in a Charismatic Christian group in Dublin called the "Shalom Fellowship" led them to question the relationship between their religious faith and the lifestyle of a rock band. Bono and the Edge considered quitting U2 due to their perceived spiritual conflicts before deciding to leave Shalom instead.

question: How many live albums did Pearl Jam release in 2000 and 2001?
answerDescription: Pearl Jam had previously allowed fans to make amateur recordings of shows. But in 2000, they decided to record and release "official bootlegs" for every concert they played on the Binaural Tour. By 2001, there were 72 of them. Several hit the chart, with the band's Nov. 6, 2001, gig in Seattle making it to No. 98.

question: What was the first rock-n-roll song to hit #1 on the charts?
answerDescription: It was not the first rock and roll record, nor was it the first successful record of the genre, but on July 9, 1955, "Rock Around the Clock" became the first rock and roll recording to hit the top of Billboard's Pop charts, a position it held for eight weeks.

question: Which Aerosmith song was nominated for both Best Original Song and Worst Original Song?
options: "I DON'T WANT TO MISS A THING"
answerDescription: "I Don't Want to Miss a Thing" was written for the 1998 natural disaster film Armageddon which starred Steven Tyler's daughter Liv Tyler. The song was nominated for both an Academy Award for Best Original Song and a Golden Raspberry Award for Worst Original Song, but lost both to "When You Believe" from The Prince of Egypt and "I Wanna Be Mike Ovitz!" from An Alan Smithee Film: Burn Hollywood Burn, respectively.

question: How many studio albums did Nirvana release?
answerDescription: For such an influential band, Nirvana ultimately released only three albums: Bleach, Nevermind, and In Utero.

question: Whose son became the Who's drummer in 1996?
answerDescription: Ringo Starr's son Zak Starkey joined the Who in 1996. Starkey had been given a drum kit by former Who drummer Keith Moon (whom he called "Uncle Keith") before his death.

question: What is the name of the Muppet modeled after Bruce Springsteen?
answerDescription: Sesame Street has performed a number of different Springsteen covers, including "Born to Add" and "Barn in the USA." The tunes have been performed by a Muppet named Bruce Stringbean who is backed by the S Street Band.

question: How old was Robert Smith when an early version of The Cure performed their first gig?
answerDescription: The founding members of the Cure were school friends at Notre Dame Middle School in Crawley, West Sussex, whose first public performance was at an end-of-year show in April 1973. 13-year-old Robert Smith and future Cure members Lol Tolhurst and Mick Dempsey formed a band called The Obelisk and played one show.

question: Which cartoon hero is in love with Sweet Polly Purebred?
answerDescription: Underdog is sweet on ace TV reporter Sweet Polly Purebred, and it is usually her cry of "Oh where, oh where has my Underdog gone?" that prompts the humble and loveable Shoeshine Boy to slip into a nearby phone booth, pop a "Super Vitamin Pill," and emerge as Underdog, champion of justice.

question: What cartoon features a team of superheroes that includes Cyborg, Beast Boy, Starfire, and Raven?
answerDescription: As the group's name suggests, the Teen Titans are a team of teenage superheroes, many of whom have acted as sidekicks to DC's premiere superheroes in the Justice League.

question: What does George Jetson's flying car transform into after he gets to work?
answerDescription: Interestingly, even though transforming into a briefcase is a feature of 21st century cars, there are car parks depicted everywhere.

question: Where do the Flintstones live?
answerDescription: Fred and Wilma live in the Stone Age town of Bedrock, which serves as the county seat of Cobblestone County, and has a population of only 2,500 people (though it does swell to 30,000 in a dream sequence in the episode "Rip Van Flintstone").

question: Inspired by an unflattering baby photo of himself, what cartoon character did Bob Clampett create in 1942?
answerDescription: Originally, Tweety was not the cute little canary that we know and love today. He started out as an aggressive, mean-spirited, pink-feathered bird named Orson who tormented two cats based on the popular comedy team Abbot and Costello. Eventually, Tweety's character and look were tweaked, and he was teamed up with Sylvester the Cat in a cartoon entitled "Tweetie Pie". This turned out to be a match made in heaven, and "Tweetie Pie" went on to become the first Warner Brothers cartoon to win an Oscar.

question: How many years after the debut of Mickey Mouse was it before Minnie Mouse made her first appearance?
answerDescription: Minnie Mouse was around from the very start, appearing with Mickey in his first film, "Plane Crazy". Patterned after the popular "flapper" girls of the time, Minnie provided a love interest for Mickey to pursue. She did not, however, make the pursuit easy, and when he first tried to kiss her during an airplane flight, she deflected his advances and parachuted to safety!

question: What blue-skinned cartoon characters took North America by storm in 1981?
answerDescription: Originally created by the Belgian cartoonist Peyo, the Smurfs, featuring such characters as Brainy Smurf, Papa Smurf, and Smurfette, were an immediate success and captured the imagination of children across North America. The show went on to win several Emmy Awards before being cancelled in 1990.

question: What cartoon characters were created when Professor Utonium accidentally added "Chemical X" to a concoction that also included sugar, spice, and everything nice?
answerDescription: When Professor Utonium set out to create the perfect little girl, he brewed up a concoction that included sugar, spice, and everything nice. Then he accidentally added "Chemical X" to the mixture and the Powerpuff Girls were born -- three super-powered girls dedicated to fighting the forces of evil and protecting the citizens of Townsville.

question: Which of the following superheroes did NOT appear in the Super Friends cartoons?
answerDescription: Hawkgirl never appeared in the original Super Friends cartoons, the producers choosing instead to go with such memorable heroes as Apache Chief, Black Vulcan, and El Dorado. However, when the more recent Justice League cartoons came out, Hawkgirl took her rightful place among DC's greatest heroes.

question: Who has a magical pet called Eugene the Jeep?
answerDescription: Popeye has a magical a pet called Eugene the Jeep. Eugene lives in a 3 dimensional world but is really a 4 dimensional creature. He answers yes/no questions by bowing down for yes and not bowing down for no. Eugene subsists on a diet of orchids.

question: Which SpongeBob Squarepants character is always trying to steal Mr. Krabs' secret formula for Krabby Patties?
answerDescription: Sheldon J. Plankton despises Mr. Krabs for running a successful restaurant because his own business rarely gets any customers.

question: Which Looney Tunes character is famous for saying "That's all, folks"?
answerDescription: In the ending of many Looney Tunes cartoons, Porky Pig bursts through a bass drum and stutters his signature line: "Th-Th-The, Th-Th-The, Th-Th ... That's all, folks!"

question: During the final season of The Flintstones, what little green alien from the planet Zetox is assigned to serve prehistoric "dumb-dumbs" Fred and Barney?
answerDescription: Exiled from his home planet Zetox for inventing a weapon capable of destroying the universe, Gazoo's punishment was to serve prehistoric "dumb-dumbs" Fred and Barney. Invisible to other adults, Gazoo provided questionable advice to his two charges and occasionally reported to his leader, the Great Gazam. The character was somewhat controversial among diehard Flintstones fans as he added a futuristic element to the otherwise prehistoric cartoon.

question: Who refused to play the part of the vultures in The Jungle Book?
answerDescription: Although Walt Disney wanted The Beatles to voice the vultures, John Lennon nixed the idea. However, the vultures were still created in The Beatles' image.

question: Which Family Guy character is obsessed with world domination?
answerDescription: Stewie, equipped with his teddy bear Rupert and his laser gun, has, on several occasions, almost single handedly taken over the world.

question: What cartoon character made his first appearance in 1919 in the five minute short "Feline Follies?"
answerDescription: Created by Otto Messmer for the Pat Sullivan Studio, Felix was a smash hit with audiences and held the title of world's most popular cartoon character for a few years until Walt Disney introduced the world to a certain mouse. Unfortunately for Felix, the Pat Sullivan Studio was behind the curve in adding sound to their cartoons, and lost much of the market to other, more technologically advanced studios like Fleischer and Disney.

question: Which two characters did the same actor voice?
answerDescription: Canadian voice actor Peter Cullen voiced both Eeyore and Optimus Prime.

question: During the first five seasons of South Park, which character died in nearly every episode?
answerDescription: Kenny died in nearly every episode before returning in the next with little-to-no explanation.

question: Which Jonny Quest character has mystical powers?
answerDescription: The seventh son of a seventh son, Jonny's best friend and adoptive brother Hadji seems to possess mystical powers (including snake-charming, levitation and hypnotism), which may or may not be attributed to parlor trickery.

question: How many nephews does Popeye have?
answerDescription: Popeye has four nephews: Pipeye, Peepeye, Pupeye, and Poopeye.

question: Where does George Jetson work?
answerDescription: He works at Spacely Space Sprockets, turning the Referential Universal Digital Indexer (R.U.D.I.) on and off.

question: What is the name of Space Ghost's spaceship?
answerDescription: The original Phantom Cruiser was painted canary yellow and shaped like a stylized bird.

question: What younger rooster does Foghorn Leghorn often try to mentor?
answerDescription: Foghorn often fancies himself a mentor figure to the younger roosters, especially Eggbert (or Egghead Jr.), tossing off bits of self-styled sagacity interjected with phrases like "Pay attention, son", or "Look at me when I'm talkin' to ya, boy."

question: What does Bugs Bunny often dare Yosemite Sam to do?
options: GIVE UP HIS LIFE OF CRIME
answerDescription: Every time Bugs dares Sam to "step across that line", he cannot help but do so, even if he steps off into empty space or down a mine shaft.

question: What religion are Betty Boop's parents?
answerDescription: Betty Boop's strict Jewish parents make only one appearance, in the cartoon Minnie the Moocher (1932). Betty's parents are all over her case, hassling her because she will not eat her sauerbaten, so Betty runs away from home with her boyfriend Bimbo--only to return after she gets lost in a haunted cave and encounters a ghostly walrus.

question: What color was Tweety Bird in his first appearance?
answerDescription: In A Tale of Two Kitties (1942), Tweety was a featherless pink baby bird. The yellow feathers were added later to satisfy censors who objected to his lack of clothing.

question: What do Smurfs eat?
answerDescription: Sarsaparilla leaves are the primary source of nutrition for the Smurfs along with smurfberries.

question: Who is Felix the Cat's archenemy?
answerDescription: The Professor (real name: Professor Nutty Nut-Meg as seen in his papers) is Felix's archenemy and, in most appearances, is trying to steal the Magic Bag of Tricks, though he always winds up failing in the end. In some episodes, when the Professor gives up on his episodic schemes, he laments: "Oh, what's the use!!!!!"

question: Which character on Friends frequently exclaims "We were on a break"?
answerDescription: When Rachel decides that she and Ross should "take a break" from their relationship, Ross takes this to mean that they've broken up and sleeps with another woman. Rachel gets back together with him the next day, but breaks up when she learns of his infidelity, prompting Ross' frequently repeated claim that "We were on a break!"

question: What does The Andy Griffith Show's Barney Fife keep in his shirt pocket?
answerDescription: Barney, Andy's inept but well-meaning deputy, has a tendency to shoot his gun, so Andy makes him keep his bullet in his shirt pocket.
